In Part One, Bok gives the lightest of skimmings to the horror genre, briefly mentioning "violent movies" and lumping together James Bond with Lethal Weapon 3 and a Chucky sequel. Title: The Uncanny Child in Transnational Cinema: Ghosts of Futurity at the Turn of the Twenty-First Century
Author: Balanzategui, Jessica
MLA 8 Citation: Balanzategui, Jessica. The Uncanny Child in Transnational Cinema: Ghosts of Futurity at the Turn of the Twenty-First Century. Amsterdam UP, 2018.
Horror Lex Summary:
Author Balanzategui applies the Freudian concept of the uncanny, an eerie patchwork between the familiar and unfamiliar, to interpret horror films featuring ghostly or supernatural children. Spooky kids, as she demonstrates, are typically depicted as victims of long-ago traumas, who haunt the present as "a challenge to the entrenched security, coherence, and power of adult knowledge and discourse."]"

Balanzategui begins with well-known examples of children in 1980s American horror cinema. These are not the Satanically possessed children of the 1970s (The Exorcist, etc.) -- they remain completely human, yet also "Other," and cause psychological entanglements with adults, such as Danny and his father in The Shining (1980). This and other key films (The Changeling, Poltergeist) also draw upon classic Freudian concepts such as doubling and traumatic repetition, reflecting shifting social structures and greater autonomy of children as economic agents. By the end of the 1990s, spirituality and the drive to find one's "inner child" had invaded American popular culture, bringing us cinematic children such as Cole in The Sixth Sense (1999), who guides oblivious adults through their concealed pasts and personal traumas.

The author also takes up the particularly striking use of uncanny children in films from two different areas of the world: Spain and Japan. In Spain, directors such as Guillermo del Toro (The Devil's Backbone) have chosen to grapple with the nation's collective memory of Francoist violence through the figure of a child seer who is caught between worlds. In Japan, starting with Ringu (1998) and the resulting J-horror boom, filmmakers have also focused on ghostly girls and boys. Balanzategui suggests this reflects national unease after the slump that followed the go-go midcentury Japanese economy. Sadako and others like her, especially as mediated through soon-to-be-obsolete technology like videotapes, are also a remodelling of the "internal alien," or an unfamiliar or unwanted second self.

Finally, Balanzategui comments on certain international co-productions and remakes (The Ring, e.g.), which have tended to uproot the supernatural child from its home in a particular place. Such children have become a "key unifying trope" of horror films around the world at the turn of the 2000s, reflecting both millennial anxieties and a "globally resonant shift in conceptualizations of childhood."

Title: They Came From Within: A History of Canadian Horror Cinema
Author: Vatnsdal, Caelum
MLA 8 Citation: Vatnsdal, Caelum. They Came From Within: A History of Canadian Horror Cinema. 2004. Revised and updated ed., ARP Books, 2014.
Horror Lex Summary:
Vatnsdal sets out his purpose in the introduction: "to bring to light the curious phenomenon and colorful history of the Canadian horror movie, and to explore any distinctive national qualities they may or may not possess." Job done, then. Bankrolled by a generous pot of public funds aimed (with curious imprecision) at building national pride, Canadians in the '70s and '80s made more than their share of horror and exploitation films, including numerous rip-offs of American and European hits. Vatnsdal begins with the repressed demons in 1962's The Mask, moves through the experiments with early '70s schlock (including Ivan Reitman's Cannibal Girls), and spends time with the big Hollywood North classics like Black Christmas, My Bloody Valentine, and Cronenberg's entire ouevre. 

Along the way, Vatnsdal does, eventually, come to understand what Canuck-o-Vision is: a fuzzy glow to the frames, small-town settings, underacting, and those accents! But whatever makes a film "smell Canadian," the country's contribution to horror cinema is legendary, and Vatnsdal's attention to detail to both the high and low art of this period borders on the obsessive (in a good way).

Title: Mythomania: Fantasies, Fables, and Sheer Lies in Contemporary American Popular Art
Author: Welt, Bernard
MLA 8 Citation: Welt, Bernard. Mythomania: Fantasies, Fables, and Sheer Lies in Contemporary American Popular Art. Art Issues Press, 1996.
Horror Lex Summary: As part of this influential collection of essays, Welt offers a guarded defense of "psycho massacre" culture with "Jason Voorhees, R.I.P." In the piece, Welt credits the Friday the 13th franchise (which was past its ninth installment, at the time) with providing "true artistry" in the form of its killer, whose hockey mask is "one of the most persistent and notorious metonymic devices in movieland, if not in recent popular culture as a whole." Low art, Welt argues, is still perceived as art, and Jason's mask is thus perceived by eager audiences as instrument, signifier, icon, and fetish, an "eerily perfect counterpart" to the 1970s Happy Face.
Films Discussed: Friday the 13th (series) (1980-2001)

Title: Corporeality and Culture: Bodies in Movement
Author: Sellberg, Karin; Lena Wånggren; and Kamillea Aghtan (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Sellberg, Karin, et al, editors. Corporeality and Culture: Bodies in Movement. 2015. Routledge, 2016.
Horror Lex Summary: As his contribution to this volume on the connection between culture and bodies (both live and dead), Aldana Reyes furthers the academic discussion on emotional or somatic reactions in film spectatorship. Aldana Reyes makes the point that a identification connection between the viewer and a character in a movie is not necessary for the viewer to sympathize, in a deep, bodily sense, with graphic violence between done to the character. Instead, we, as owners of physical bodies who understand vulnerability, discomfort, pain, identify with the representation of his/her body -- as in the Saw series, when we grimace and turn away at scenes of gore and dismemberment even when reprehensible characters are the victims.
Films Discussed:
Aldana Reyes, Xavier - Mobilising Affect: Somatic Empathy and the Cinematic Body in Distress
・Paranormal Activity (2007)
・Saw III (2006)
・Saw 3D: The Final Chapter (2010)
Tags: body horror, biology, emotions, torture porn, gore, psychoanalysis, cognitive science

Title: I Lost it at the Movies
Author: Kael, Pauline
MLA 8 Citation: Kael, Pauline. I Lost it at the Movies. 1965. Marion Boyars, 2011.
Horror Lex Summary: One of many compendia of the film reviews of Pauline Kael, the longtime New York Times film critic who passed away in 2001. Here, she dips into horror-lite territory with a review of The Innocents (1960), which she deems "not a great movie, but it's a very good one," with affecting visual touches that she attributes to the director Jack Clayton as well as cinematographer Freddie Francis. The beauty they created "raises our terror to a higher plane than the simple fears of most ghost stories." Most entertaining, Kael adds some well-earned jibes at fellow critics who savaged or misunderstood the film.
Films Discussed: The Innocents (1960)

Title: The Silence of the Lambs (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Forshaw, Barry
MLA 8 Citation: Forshaw, Barry. The Silence of the Lambs. Auteur, 2013.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

Forshaw's ode to Jonathan Demme's The Silence of the Lambs (1991) begins with unconditional praise for Thomas Harris, the author of the adapted novel as well as the entire Hannibal Lecter series, and "now the yardstick by which all other modern thriller novelists are judged." While a bit breathless, Forshaw does well to remind us that Silence (the film) did not arise in a vaccum, but rather took full advantage of Harris's best-selling plotting, pacing, and knack for dialogue. 

From there, Forshaw spends most of this volume performing a scene-by-scene read of the film. He deconstructs particularly resonant set pieces (such as the meticulously structured initial meeting between Clarice Starling and Hannibal Lecter, and Lecter's killing of the guards, "an almost text-book example of audience manipulation") and highlights the award-winning performances from Anthony Hopkins, Jodie Foster, and Ted Levine (Buffalo Bill). While Forshaw limits himself almost entirely to a textual read of the film, he does occasionally go below surface level, pointing to Silence's recurrent themes: socioeconomic class, duality, and metamorphosis. In an interesting aside, he identifies the latter as the true purpose of Buffalo Bill's likely faux homosexuality or transgender identity, an aspect of the film that triggered unexpected (although arguably deserved) controversy.

Sandwiching Forshaw's walk-through of the film are his discussions of the progenitors of Silence -- including Psycho but also Manhunter, the first Harris adaptation and Lecter cinematic appearance -- and its successors. In the latter category, he must acknowledge the head-scratching (and rushed) Hannibal and the polarizing Hannibal Rising, plus the crime procedurals of David Fincher (Se7en, Zodiac). 

A serviceable, if superficial, autopsy of the film.

Title: The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Rose, James
MLA 8 Citation: Rose, James. The Texas Chain Saw Massacre. Auteur, 2013.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

A quick read on Tobe Hooper's 1974 masterpiece, The Texas Chain Saw Massacre. For those in need of the most basics of basics, Rose starts with an essay summarizing the genesis, torturous production, and distribution of the film. He then launches into a series of short chapters addressing particularly meaningful facets of the film, including its attempted censorship by the British film board, a close reading of the film's opening images and titles, and a walk-through of key scenes of violence and set pieces (such as the grotesque "Room of Feather and Bone" that character Pam wanders into). Throughout, Rose makes the case for viewing the film as a modern take on gothic tropes and Freud's concept of the uncanny.
Films Discussed:
Eggshells (1969)
The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (1974)
The Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2 (1986)
The Texas Chainsaw Massacre (2003)
Tags: Tobe Hooper, censorship, gothic, serial killers, true crime, Leatherface, family, families, Freud, Final Girl

Title: Carrie (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Mitchell, Neil
MLA 8 Citation: Mitchell, Neil. Carrie. Auteur, 2014.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

Carrie, arguably the best film adaptation of a Stephen King novel, gets the full treatment. Author Mitchell argues that the film "is a clear product of '70s America," reflecting the decade's upheaval in terms of gender, youth vs. age, and trust in authorities. "Human monsters" -- including those, like Carrie White, who play a dual role of antagonist and hero -- began overshadowing more animalistic baddies on screen, violence became more graphic, and film resolutions became more nihilistic. Within this context, Mitchell analyzes the film's major themes of religion, the supernatual (and its link to Carrie White's pubescent status), adolescence, gender, and authority, plus its recurring motifs, such as blood and duality/split images. 

The rest of the book is dedicated to the basics: the writing of the novel (a project that King, famously, nearly abandoned) and Carrie White's real-life inspiration; a biographical sketch of director Brian DePalma, including a detailed account of his filmmaking style up to Carrie and consideration (and the author's rejection) of his alleged misogyny;production history of the film; scene-by-scene review; and critical reception and influence.

Title: The Thing (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Conolly, Jez
MLA 8 Citation: Conolly, Jez. The Thing. Auteur, 2014.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

John Carpenter's 1982 film The Thing may go down in horror history as the film most reviled upon its release but most beloved with the passage of time. Conolly dedicates this monograph to the film's legacy.

Conolly deliberately eschews the linear plot walk-through approach, although he does provide a quick and entertaining mini-summary. He then gets into the meat of the film with essays on its most salient attributes: the visual landscape of the film, a blanket of harsh white wilderness that has inspired numerous stories of other-worldly arctic beasts (as well as the source material for the film, John Campbell's Who Goes There?); the look of Carpenter's Thing monster, a twisted, gory nightmare reflecting the particular anxieties of the late '70s/early '80s, and contributing mightily to what we know call "body horror"; the gliding movement and framing of the camera; and its famously bleak ending. 

Here and there, Conolly also offers novel insights and theories, such as his suggestion that the Thing bears a magnetic pull that throws off the laws of physics, turning the inside to the outside, up to down. He also notices subtle plot cues and unanswered questions that even dedicated fans may have missed.

Another winner from the Devil's Advocate series that should give fans of The Thing plenty to think about.
Films Discussed:
Alien (1979)
The Shining (1980)
South of Sanity (2012)
The Thing (1982)
The Thing (2011)
The Thing from Another World (1951)
Tags: John Carpenter, special effects, makeup, aliens, cinematography, body horror, sci fi, science fiction

Title: Halloween (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Leeder, Murray
MLA 8 Citation: Leeder, Murray. Halloween. Auteur, 2015.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

Given Halloween (1978)'s place in history as one of the most popular and influential horror films, as well as the ur text for modern slashers, there is a rich body of information about it already recorded. As a result, this book could have been a mere summarization of all the standard backstory and making-of facts that can be found on innumerable special edition DVDs. But this is no Halloween 101; this is Advanced Halloween Studies. Leeder has an eagle eye for the enduring debates about this film that matter the most, and brought a few new ones to the class.

Some of Leeder's analysis is textual, such as his praise for the deft use of the floating Panaglide camera and how Michael Myers' movements are punctuated by sparse music and stingers. He also discusses in detail the added scenes in the extended TV edition of the film; useful, given that that version is rare. 

The bulk of this book, however, is devoted to more conceptual topics. Leeder gives an entire chapter to history of the Halloween holiday and the film's deliberate evocation of its themes of childhood mischief and masked anonymity. He also draws a portrait of Dr. Loomis as a (failed) psychiatrist and finds parallels in the narrative with Lovecraft - two angles not covered in other writings on Halloween. Throughout, Leeder draws upon his own interviews with director John Carpenter, which provide new insights.
Films Discussed:
Black Christmas (1974)
The Changeling (1980)
The Fog (1980)
Halloween (1978)

Title: Suspiria (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Heller-Nicholas, Alexandra
MLA 8 Citation: Heller-Nicholas, Alexandra. Suspiria. Auteur, 2016.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

Right away, author Heller-Nicholas sets aside common criticism of Suspiria that it doesn't make a lick of sense. Appreciating the film is "not so much to understand [it] intellectually" but "experience it sensorially," she writes. Suspiria,often said to be director Dario Argento's finest film, intentionally flouts traditional cinematic plotting and "aggressively mocks any attempt at realism." 

After a lightning-round overview of the Italian horror tradition and Argento's oeuvre, Heller-Nicholas spends the bulk of the book on the inspiration for Suspiria (including a focus on Daria Nicolodi's role, a fact often neglected by other authors), its production, a scene-by-scene analysis, and reception. The book is peppered with quotations from interviews with cast and crew, and includes the full text of the author's personal interview with Suspiria cinematographer, Luciano Tovoli. The latter is a real treat, especially when Tovoli recounts his initial proposal of literally throwing paint in primary colors onto the actors, and ultimately settling for the use of colored velvets over the lights.

Title: The Blair Witch Project (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Turner, Peter
MLA 8 Citation: Turner, Peter. The Blair Witch Project. Auteur, 2015.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

Turner pens this monograph about the still-infamous found-footage horror film The Blair Witch Project, which, just before the turn of the millennium, changed the face of independent film production forever. The micro-budgeted and sparse story -- three twenty-somethings venture into a Maryland forest in pursuit of a legendary child-killing witch -- was an unlikely candidate to cause a sea change in the world of cinema. Yet even before its release, its reputation was made as a "glowing example of what could be achieved with cheap emerging technology, imagination and a less is more approach."

Turner first turns to the mechanics of the film, focusing on the filmmakers' novel approach to financing and the film's production. Notable here are the details on the extremely Method tactics enforced by the directors -- essentially, throwing the three actors into the woods, tired, hungry, and terrorized in the night by hidden cast members, and then making them improvise the dialogue as well as keep the handheld cameras rolling.

Here is where many monographs dive into the "meaning" of the film. But as Turner implicitly acknowledges, the legacy of Blair Witch is not about its textual interpretation, but rather its cultural impact, of which the faux-documentary style and marketing of the film was undeniably the largest part. The author pieces together what made Blair Witch so effective in purporting to be the real footage of a real documentary crew, including its reliance on well-known cinéma verité techniques, plus the impact of its subjective, diagetic camera. Turner also devotes a chapter to the unprecedented viral marketing campaign that surrounded the film, including its website (blairwitch.com) that "completely destabilized audience perceptions of the film as either real or fake."
Films Discussed:
The Blair Witch Project (1999)
Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 (2000)
Cannibal Holocaust (1980)
Lady in the Lake (1946)
The Last Broadcast (1998)
Tags: found footage, cinematography, marketing, women, female, witches, witchcraft, social media, fan culture

Title: The Curse of Frankenstein (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Harmes, Marcus K.
MLA 8 Citation: Harmes, Marcus K. The Curse of Frankenstein. Auteur, 2015.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

Right off the bat, Harmes recognizes the dubious legacy of The Curse of Frankenstein (1957) as the film that launched the gothic period of Hammer Films. While wildly popular for a long stretch, Hammer's films eventually dropped off in creativity and quality, becoming little more than sexploitation. As the author notes, "Curse is thus not only regarded as the beginning of a tradition, but a tradition that outstayed its welcome." He refuses to assign Curse to the dustbin of history, however, and insists it be recognized as a revolutionary change in British cinema. 

Much of the book is taken up by Harmes' meditation on what constitutes a successful film adaptation of literature, firmly rejecting the idea that faithfulness to the text is the sine qua non. Instead, Harmes argues, in Curse, director Terence Fisher created a "dramatically powerful hybrid" of literary adaptation and disparate film styles, creating an ultimate product that shows adaptation can work in a "more organic and provocative" manner. Moreover, the film almost single-handedly restarted the concept of the British horror film, in shocking fashion. What was derided at the time as excessive gore (e.g., detached eyeballs demurely placed into a glass jar) would hardly raise an eyebrow today, but in an era when Royal Navy epics and stuffy costume dramas were what passed for national cinema, detached body parts "must have seemed freakishly bizarre." 

In his deep-dive into the film, Harmes also notes details that will likely interest fans of Curse, such as the starkness of the Eastman color process, making reds garishly pop; parallels between Curse and the similarly derided Peeping Tom (1960); and the relationship between Hammer's films and those of the older, more established Gainsborough studios.
Films Discussed:
The Curse of Frankenstein (1957)
Dracula (1931)
Frankenstein (1931)
Frankenstein (a.k.a. Edison's Frankenstein) (1910)
Horror of Dracula (a.k.a. Dracula) (1958)
Mary Shelley's Frankenstein (1994)
Peeping Tom (1960)

Title: Frightmares: A History of British Horror Cinema
Author: Cooper, Ian
MLA 8 Citation: Cooper, Ian. Frightmares: A History of British Horror Cinema. Auteur, 2016.
Horror Lex Summary:
With its history of urbane murderers, Gothic poets, and ghoulish sebsibilities, author Cooper finds Great Britain to be fertile ground for horror, despite its genre tradition being "ignored and maligned" until recently. His book celebrates the British horror film and its "fascination with the seamy, the sensational, and the sometimes staggeringly tasteless."

Frightmares is partly a narrative history and partly a well-curated encyclopedia of key films, actors, and directors, with mini-essays discussing the contribution of each scattered throughout the book. Cooper begins with pre-1950s "shockers," the gems of which were overshadowed by the big American successes such as Frankenstein. Then, a long chapter devoted to the films of Hammer Studios, perhaps England's greatest genre export, with a focus on lesser-known examples of their productions, such as Horrors of the Black Museum (1959). The next chapters cover three decades of Brit film: the 1970s rise of AIP studios, Roger Corman, and Vincent Price (e.g., Dr. Phibes); the darker tone of the "grim '70s" (Death Line, Frenzy); and the 1970s influx of foreign directors. Cooper concludes with a look at the "dog days" of British horror and censorship (the "video nasties" debate) and the new wave of British horror that arose after the new millennium (The Kill List).

Title: Folk Horror: Hours Dreadful and Things Strange
Author: Scovell, Adam
MLA 8 Citation: Scovell, Adam. Folk Horror: Hours Dreadful and Things Strange. Auteur, 2017.
Horror Lex Summary:
As author Scovell details, the definition of "folk horror" is elusive, but loosely describes films imbuing themselves with a sense of the arcane, or creating their own, using a variety of pastoral, place-driven narratives. Scovell starts his tour with the "trinity" of folk horror (Witchfinder General, Blood on Satan's Claw, and The Wicker Man) each of which arose from British counterculture of the 1960s, when paganism and witchcraft were no longer considered pure fantasy. 

The remaining chapters are organized by topic: the horror of topography, where Scovell concentrates on episodes of 1960s-1980s BBC television that depicted hauntings springing from the land itself; rurality, primarily in the British Isles (seen in Hammer films and Straw Dogs) but also abroad (Haxan, Picnic at Hanging Rock, Onibaba); and the rise of occultism in film to explore modern prejudices and ethics (Burn, Witch, Burn; The Devils), including through depictions of the "urban wyrd" (Death Line). He ends with a nod to the modern folk horror revival. While heavily powered by nostalgia, these newer works often link modern political issues to folk narratives. Here, he examines (among others) The Witch (which "put folklorically psychological material back into the cinematic mainstream") and director Ben Wheatley's Kill List and A Field in England.

Title: The Films of Terence Fisher: Hammer Horror and Beyond (original title: The Charm of Evil: The Life and Films of Terence Fisher)
Author: Dixon, Wheeler Winston
MLA 8 Citation: Dixon, Wheeler Winston. The Films of Terence Fisher: Hammer Horror and Beyond. Auteur, 2018.

Title: The Shining (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Mee, Laura
MLA 8 Citation: Mee, Laura. The Shining. Auteur, 2017.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

As with most of the Devil’s Advocates volumes, Mee dispenses with a scene-by-scene breakdown, focusing instead on The Shining's legacy and its status as a particularly bright spot in director Stanley Kubrick’s eclectic oeuvre. 

Mee devotes a chapter to the now-infamous rift between Kubrick and author Stephen King, providing a well-researched account of the director’s approach to adapting King’s novel for the screen and King’s frustration with Kubrick’s seeming lack of appreciation for the supernatural aspect of the storyline. In Chapter 4, Mee explores The Shining's place in the post-Psycho horror pantheon that locates horror within the nuclear family. Here, the author offers a defense of Shelley Duvall’s performance as Wendy and discusses the arguably racist turn of the African-American character Dick Halloran from survivor-hero into mere slaughter fodder. 

Mee ends with a fascinating chapter on the significant amount of marketing of the film upon release, which was largely undone by critics' and audiences' collective head-scratching, which Mee chalks up to an unfair expectation that The Shining would be a straight-forward horror tale. But as she notes, if history is the judge, The Shining has eventually triumphed, and leaves a litany of pop-culture references in its shadow.
Films Discussed:
The Amityville Horror (1979)
The Babadook (2014)
It Follows (2014)
Psycho (1960)
Room 237 (2012)
The Shining (1980)
The Shining (TV miniseries) (1997)
The Witch (2015)
Tags: Stanley Kubrick, Stephen King, cinematography, Freud, literature, family, families, patriarchy, race, racism, Black, African-American, marketing

Title: Candyman (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Towlson, Jon
MLA 8 Citation: Towlson, Jon. Candyman. Auteur, 2018.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

Candyman was a breath of fresh air in the otherwise stagnating horror scene of 1992, a non-sequel with an original storyline and a strangely romantic, compelling monster. In this entry in the Devil's Advocates series, author Towson pays tribute to this enduring film and explores its meaning. He provides all the standard mechanics — an introduction to Clive Barker (on whose short story Candyman is based) and director/screenwriter Bernard Rose, casting and production trivia, discussion of the reception by audiences and critics, and a nod to the sequels. 

The meat of the book is Chapter 4, Towlson’s scene-by-scene, textual analysis of the film in which he grapples with the twin centers of the movie — race and gender — albeit with a much heavier focus on the latter. Towlson examines the character of Helen (Virginia Madsen) in light of the concepts of abjection and the “Paranoid Woman” trope, and notes that ultimately, the film is about her transcendence. Yet he recognizes “making a white woman the focus of a film that ostensibly tackles the subject of racist remains, for many critics, problematic.” Upon surveying many others' viewpoints, he concludes that the film is simultaneously racially progressive and regressive (although certainly does not provide the last word on the matter). 

At the back of the book is a new interview with Rose from 2016 in which he reflects on his career in film and music videos, and identifies the biggest film influences on Candyman, mostly from Polanski.

Title: Frenzy (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Cooper, Ian
MLA 8 Citation: Cooper, Ian. Frenzy. Auteur, 2018.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

Frenzy, Hitchcock's penultimate film, may be his most disreputable. "Repulsive," it was called at the time; the film's explicit depiction of rape-murders by the "Necktie Strangler" and overall deep-1970s English grime left a bad taste in many a viewer's (and reviewer's) mouth. Author Cooper does not exactly defend the film, but he does help one better understand its place in Hitchcock's oeuvre. 

Cooper begins this bite-sized book (less than a hundred mini-pages) with a history of three, real-life "genteel, polite yet brutal killers" with whom Hitchcock seemed so taken. They, along with Arthur La Bern's novel Goodbye Piccadilly, Farewell Leicester Square, inspired certain earlier films as well as Frenzy. Cooper next provides pages of facts on the casting, locations, and production, including some choice bits of gossip -- such as Michael Caine refusing a lead role after finding the script "disgusting." Eschewing the typical scene-by-scene breakdown, Cooper instead addresses major themes of the film: fascination with "the British Murder," food/sex imagery, depictions of rape and mistreatment of women, and why films of the '70s exuded such notable sleaze.

Frenzy (1972)

Title: In the Mouth of Madness (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Blyth, Michael
MLA 8 Citation: Blyth, Michael. In the Mouth of Madness. Auteur, 2018.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

Author Blyth goes to bat for John Carpenter's underseen and underloved 1994 film, In the Mouth of Madness. In just over 100 tiny pages, he does his best to establish that the film is "a sophisticated think piece on horror, exploring the deep philosophical and socio-political implications of a then-unfashionable genre."

Blyth first places the movie in the context of the mid-1990s (pre-Scream) dull spot in horror history, noting that even Carpenter himself admitted "it's a bad time for horror." After a quick film recap and an introduction to Carpenter's Apocalypse Trilogy (In the Mouth of Madness being the final of the three), Blyth devotes a chapter to the Lovecraftian inspiration for the film, declaring that Carpenter is one of the few filmmakers who has seriously attempted to bring Lovecraft's vision of cosmic horror to the screen. More than a simple monster movie, Madness evokes "devastating, pessimistic nihilism." Another chapter is dedicated to Stephen King, the clear inspiration for main character Sutter Cane, and other literary antecedents. In the remaining chapters, Blyth explores major themes of the film: theology and fanaticism (including parallels with Scientology); self-reflexivity, as a horror film about horror; and "seeing" in a literal and figurative sense.
Films Discussed:
In the Mouth of Madness (1994)
Prince of Darkness (1987)
The Thing (1982)
Videodrome (1983)
Wes Craven's New Nightmare (1994)
Tags: John Carpenter, H.P. Lovecraft, Stephen King, 1990s, religion, Scientology, Satan, devil

Title: It Follows (Devil's Advocates Series)
Author: Grimm, Joshua
MLA 8 Citation: Grimm, Joshua. It Follows. Auteur, 2018.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Auteur's Devil's Advocates is a series of books devoted to exploring the classics of horror cinema.)

Author Grimm provides a short study of It Follows, the breakout indie horror hit of 2014. This is primarily a personal, textual reading, peppered by Grimm's unremarkable (and sometimes arguable) observations about the horror genre. That said, Grimm provides a few discussion-worthy asides about the film, including a meditation on what the nature of what "it" is (clearly supernatural, but not entirely composed of any familiar antecedent such as demon, zombie, or serial killer); a discussion of the film's use of time disruption; and a tour of the different spaces and neighborhoods visited in the film, which take on new significance "in a film about having room to escape an unstoppable entity."

Title: The Moment of Psycho: How Alfred Hitchcock Taught America to Love Murder
Author: Thomson, David
MLA 8 Citation: Thomson, David. The Moment of Psycho: How Alfred Hitchcock Taught America to Love Murder. Basic Books, 2009.
Horror Lex Summary:
A laser-focused essay on Alfred Hitchcock's crowning achievement of the thriller genre: Psycho. Author Thomson follows the film's plot beat by beat, noting where the director's expert touch creates unbearable suspense or shock, and providing observations on the finished product in the context of its time (such as his comment that Marion Crane being clad in just a bra and half-slip "in the code of 1960 ... is 'naked'"). He also comments on the aspects of Psycho that indelibly mark it a Hitchcock work, such as his virtual torture of its leading actress, who is "remorselessly studied for forty minutes and then torn to pieces." He adds nibbles of information along the way about Tony Perkins' bravura performance, Paramount's hand-wringing over the release of the film, attempts at censorship, novel marketing tactics, critical reception, and a short list of other films (indexed below) that Thomson claims are indebted to Psycho.

The Psycho shower scene, Thomson observes, forever changed audience expectations of horror, just at the right time in the midcentury collective consciousness. Whether this "moment" was a revelation of our truly violent human nature, or just a new threshhold of filmmaking, is arguable. But unquestionably, Hitchcock proved that "this medium was prepared for an outrage in which sex and violence were no longer games but were in fact everything."

Title: Monsters and Mad Scientists: A Cultural History of the Horror Movie
Author: Tudor, Andrew
MLA 8 Citation: Tudor, Andrew. Monsters and Mad Scientists: A Cultural History of the Horror Movie. Basil-Blackwell, 1989.
Horror Lex Summary:
In Monsters and Mad Scientists, British professor and writer Andrew Tudor wrote one of the first books to parse horror films as an academic subject. His approach is (as he explains) sociological in nature rather than Freudian, as was de rigeur at the time of the book's publication. Tudor thus avoids looking for deep symbolism, and instead asks how the "practical consciousness" of the moviegoing public perceived these films. 

The book is based on Tudor's dataset of 990 horror films released from 1931-1984, ending just after the slasher boom (which unfortunately means his review is long out of date). Once he has those films, Tudor is then obsessed with putting them in boxes. He categorizes the type and style of film on multiple axes of his own making, such as whether the horror is "internal" (like in Halloween and other psycho killer movies) or "external" (like classic monster movies), and whether the central monster is sexual, supernatural, or psychotic in nature. He even includes trend charts based on statistics run from his own categorizations. The result is a bit bloodless, and more than a little reminiscent of that week in English class you spent diagramming sentences.

Yet Monsters and Mad Scientists remains well-known and oft-quoted for a few of its key observations. Primary among them is Tudor's identification of 1960, the year of Psycho, as the dividing line between classic horror of the "secure" era (the monster is defeated, social order restored) and the beginning of the "paranoid" era (everything is bad, nothing will ever be the same). Tudor's observations as to which types of narratives were more common from decade to decade -- such as the rise of invasion films in the '50s and the increasing proximity of killers to the family unit in the '70s -- are also on-point, and in fact have become standard horror history.

Title: Uncontrollable Bodies: Testimonies of Identity and Culture
Author: Sappington, Rodney and Tyler Stallings (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Sappington, Rodney, and Tyler Stallings, editors. Uncontrollable Bodies: Testimonies of Identity and Culture. Bay Press, 1994.
Horror Lex Summary: In this collection of essays about the human body and the "cultural forces acting to define it," cultural critic Vivian Sobchack considers a relatively obscure 1960s horror film, The Leech Woman, and its kin of the era. The "scary woman" of horror, Sobchack observes, can be threatening because of her viciousness, or, in contrast, because of her weakness, her proximity to abjection and death. The titular Leech Woman, the 50 Foot Woman, the Wasp Woman, with their fading beauty and concomitant rage, tap into the (male) fear of "inappropriate and transgressive sexual desire that lingers through the very process of aging, physical degradation, and decay."

Title: Gospel of the Living Dead: George Romero's Visions of Hell on Earth
Author: Paffenroth, Kim
MLA 8 Citation: Paffenroth, Kim. Gospel of the Living Dead: George Romero's Visions of Hell on Earth. Baylor UP, 2006.
Horror Lex Summary:
Many critics have seen George A. Romero's zombies as allegories -- for destructive consumption, social conformity, and a host of unhealthy -isms. Paffenroth instead takes a theological view: zombies are what they are because they're plagued with our sins. His Gospel of the Living Dead is loosely framed as a companion to Dante's Inferno, where hell is a torment of own making and sinners of different kinds populate levels of the underworld. Paffenroth takes up just the essential Romero cannon -- Night of the Living Dead (1968) through Land of the Living Dead (2005), plus one remake -- and postulates on the particular sins depicted in each, from pride to materialism to domination. Only in Land of the  Dead, he argues, does Romero finally anticipate humans and zombies expiating their shared sins and rebuilding a more egalitarian society.

The author deliberately intends to moralize here, but the book is hardly preachy -- and, note, it won a Bram Stoker Award. While he does provide a solidly Christian view of religion (Roman Catholic, in particular), he espouses a progressive social viewpoint throughout, for example, by faulting the men in Day of the Dead for their misogyny and racism as much as their sinful violence. Given their similarity to humans, zombies have been a useful figure on which to project any number of our fears and social ills, and Paffenroth shows they are plenty capable of bearing our crises of faith as well.

Dawn of the Dead (1978)
Dawn of the Dead (2004)
Day of the Dead (1985)

Night of the Living Dead (1968)

Title: Monsters in America: Our Historical Obsession with the Hideous and the Haunting
Author: Poole, W. Scott
MLA 8 Citation: Poole, W. Scott. Monsters in America: Our Historical Obsession with the Hideous and the Haunting. Baylor UP, 2011.
Horror Lex Summary:
As he warns in the Preface, author Poole is not here to give us a definition of a monster. Instead, he intends to let American history do that for us. Monsters in America is first and foremost a book of history -- about the violence, wars, social upheaval, and exploration that make up the very core of what we think of as the United States. Within that very long story are fictional monsters, often human or human-created, that serve as the reification and expiation of very real monsters in American life, from the whip-holding slave owner to communism. Poole intends to address why we cannot simply identify the monster as a metaphor for something that repels or frightens us as individuals -- because we often embrace our monsters at a societal level (or at least are titillated by it), revealing that the monsters are not separable from our own world views, nor do they simply reflect our own idiosyncratic psyches.

Poole has selected his eras with care, and avoids the war-to-war cycle that so many other historians use to make their way through the 17th-21st centuries. He starts with the settling of the country by white Europeans and the nearly instant, violent clash with Native Americans, moving through the post-Civil War years, the Great American Sleep of the 1950s, the 1980s Satanic Panic, the body obsession era of the late 20th century, and the post 9/11 world. In each chapter, Poole picks a few films that encapsulate the monsters of the time, such as Freaks (1932) and Frankenstein (1931), released during a time of unprecedented racist imagery depicting African-Americans and immigrants as monsters and hysteria over racial mixing. Poole has a knack for finding lesser-known corners of the horror world, including the American preoccupation with sea monsters (!) in the early days of the nation and midcentury stories of sexual encounters with aliens, a manifestation of very real societal changes in the acceptance of sexuality.

This is not a feel-good history lesson; racism and social strife come up at every turn. Intentionally so -- the thread going through the entire book is about how violence defines us as Americans and "how monster tales have been used as exhibitions of power over the oppressed." 

Monsters in America is far more than the rather lazy search for easy metaphors that you get from so many other writings (yeah, Godzilla is the A-bomb, we get it). Poole is an impecceable researcher and a highly engaging writing, and this is as much a nice brush-up on American history as it is a book about horror. Maybe you and your parents can read the same book for once?

Title: Merchants of Menace: The Business of Horror Cinema
Author: Nowell, Richard (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Nowell, Richard, editor. Merchants of Menace: The Business of Horror Cinema. Bloomsbury Academic, 2014.
Horror Lex Summary:
Nowell has carved out a niche in the world of horror academia, focusing his research and writing almost exclusively on horror movies as an industry - meaning their financing, production, distribution, marketing, and box office returns. While some readers may find industrial review saps all the fun out of monster flicks, many will find it refreshing to look at these films from a more practical and less artistic or symbolic perspective.

In Merchants of Menace, Nowell farms out most of the writing to contributors, many of whom are well-known writers on the horror genre. Chapter 11 from Mikal J. Gaines is a particular standout, looking at how the press and audiences in African-American communities responded to horror films in the 1950s-1960s, some of which were blatantly racist and equated blackness with monstrosity, and others appeared to poke fun at such tropes and were marketed directly to minority viewers. Gaines relates "how black media facilitated a dialog about the movies while being used to sell a product that had rarely been conceived with black spectators in mind." Also notable is Nowell's own essay (Chapter 8) in which he gives a different kind star treatment to Jamie Lee Curtis, Scream Queen of the early 1980s. Nowell explores how Curtis's status as the repeat lead actress in early '80s slashers was at least in part a business decision, given that her famous lineage and warm personality (at least partially the product of careful branding) helped counteract negative reputation of such films and move them into the fold of mainstream Hollywood.

Title: Grindhouse: Cultural Exchange on 42nd Street, and Beyond
Author: Fisher, Austin and Johnny Walker (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Fisher, Austin and Johnny Walker, editors. Grindhouse: Cultural Exchange on 42nd Street, and Beyond. Bloomsbury Academic, 2016.
Horror Lex Summary:
New York's 42nd Street (which currently resembles a midwestern mall) in the not-too-recent past was seen as the "hub of sensational thrills, vice and excess." This was based in part on the "grindhouse" theaters that lined the blocks off Times Square, grinding out a stream of violence, gore, and nude flesh. While other grindhouse histories do little more than gush about this seamy past, editors Fisher and Walker are more sober-minded. As they point out in the introduction, just because trash is now cool doesn't turn all trash into art. And so they have assembled an impressive roster of contributors to turn a critical eye to the grindhouse aesthetic, or "paracinema," and its cultural significance.

The scope of the book is impressive, reaching into far corners of grindhouse cinema, such as biker films, blaxploitation westerns, and even "Indiansploitation." Horror fans, however, will most appreciate three chapters. In Chapter 1, Glenn Ward makes the bold claim that the iconic "grindhouse" film is a recent invention (blaming Tarantino and other "cultists") and that the 42nd Street mythos is far tamer when viewed with the eyes of history rather than fandom. In Chapter 3, author Brandum tells the history of the infamous Italian cannibal films as experienced by audiences in Melbourne in the late 1970s/early 1980s. Through some painstaking research into local theater marketing, he reveals that Australia had no "grindhouse" cultureto speak of, and thus these films were aimed at a suburban, middle-class audience, who experienced these films alongside standard Hollywood fare. Finally, we're back in Oz in Chapter 9, where Alexandra Heller-Nicholas discusses the world of Ozploitation films, including genre-reflective horror flicks such as Dead-End Drive-In and Thirst.

Title: What's Eating You? Food and Horror on Screen
Author: Miller, Cynthia J. and A. Bowdoin Van Riper (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Miller, Cynthia J., and A. Bowdoin Van Riper, editors. What's Eating You? Food and Horror on Screen. Bloomsbury Academic, 2017.
Horror Lex Summary: As editors Miller and Van Riper explain, food isn't just about sustenance; it's about belief systems. What we choose to eat, what we forbid from being eaten, and our own fear of being eaten (by fellow human or beast) are deeply ingrained into our identities. Thus the editors present this series of essays about food and eating in the horror film, from Hollywood hits to obscurities (seriously, this may be the only chance you have to witness an academic take on Poultrygeist). Among the best entries: Thomas Prasch's deconstruction of The Cook, The Thief, His Wife & Her Lover as Thatcherist critique and historical allusion (Ch. 6); Tom Hertweck's examination of cannibalism bringing two women together in Chul-Soo Park's 301/302 (Ch. 8); Erin Wiegand's survey of cannibal-savage movies of the late 1970s and the link between the animal and human deaths depicted within (Ch. 15); and Vivian Halloran's fun history lesson on meat pies as coffins (one for your "I did not know that!" file) (Ch. 19). And a special gold star goes to contributor Mark Henderson for managing to pen a grown-up discussion of consumerism and classism in the Human Centipede series that is surprisingly...tasteful (sorry) (Ch. 11).

Title: Fashioning Horror: Dressing to Kill on Screen and in Literature
Author: Petrov, Julia and Gudrun D. Whitehead
MLA 8 Citation: Petrov, Julia, and Gudrun D. Whitehead. Fashioning Horror: Dressing to Kill on Screen and in Literature. Bloomsbury Academic, 2018.
Horror Lex Summary:
Authors Gudrun and Whitehead, along with their contributors, examine the horrifying aspects of ritual dress and adornment as expressed in literature and film. 

About half the chapters deal with film, including twin chapters on the garb of Frankenstein (the male monster) and his Bride (the female monster) from authors Jaeb and Lublin. The authors note how the original clothing and hairstyles (er, headstyles?) chosen for both figures in the 1930s films emphasis one's deathly origins but the other's femininity. In Chapter 5, author McKnight tells the history of the Jack the Ripper murders and the prominent role that his victims' class-revealing clothing played in contemporaneous news stories, only to be sensationalized with heaving breasts and tight corsets in later films and fashions. The last three chapters delve into the realm of the slasher, addressing Halloween costuming as a metamorphosing device in Halloween 4: The Return of Michael Myers (1988) (Chapter 9); masks that reveal the personality and motives of the slasher (Chapter 10); and films that invoke the cultural myth of the foolkiller, as used by Edgar Allan Poe in his story "Hop-Frog" (Chapter 11).

On a horror-TV note, in Chapter 7, author Lezama notes how the attire of the zombies in The Walking Dead not only marks their abjection but also places them in a social class far apart from men like Dr. Lecter in Hannibal, whose dandyish formality marks him as part of the "unproductive elite," with an elegance that allows him (or urges him?) to kill the bourgeoisie.

While not concerning film, Stephanie Bowry's Chapter 2 has an interesting take on vampires of 20th-century literature, including Anne Rice's Lestat, and how their finery, including the color red and uncanny wedding dresses, become part of their human masquerade through the ages. Wedding dresses come up again in Chapter 4, with author Heaton looking to gothic writers like Wilkie Collins whose texts rely upon the "ritualized expression of femininity" in bridal gowns to create white-clad doppelgangers of doom.

Title: Opening Wednesday at a Theater or Drive-in Near You: The Shadow Cinema of the American '70s
Author: Taylor, Charles
MLA 8 Citation: Taylor, Charles. Opening Wednesday at a Theater or Drive-in Near You: The Shadow Cinema of the American '70s. Bloomsbury USA, 2017.
Horror Lex Summary: Most books dedicated to 1970s cinema will focus on the output of the auteurs -- The Godfathers and The Last Picture Shows of the decade. Taylor tells you upfront: this book is not about those movies. Instead, it's a love letter to the "horror movies, biker pictures, nudie teasers, women's prison pictures, moonshiner sagas, phony documentaries...and Eurosleaze exploitation pictures" that graced the indoor and outdoor screens of America, ignored by critics but gobbled up by those in search of lurid, "adult" thrills. Most refreshing is that Taylor does not simply provide a film encyclopedia. Instead, each chapter focuses on a single film, with Taylor providing his take on the film's historical and social context. For Eyes of Laura Mars -- which, really more of a giallo, is the most solidly "horror" film highlighted in the book -- Taylor invokes the grime of 1970s New York City and the Rolling Stone's album Some Girls to place the film in the  category of "sleaze as high chic."

Title: Cut: The Unseen Cinema
Author: Phillips, Baxter
MLA 8 Citation: Phillips, Baxter. Cut: The Unseen Cinema. Random House, 1988.
Horror Lex Summary: Phillips devotes his book to censorship of performance arts, particularly film, through the ages based on too much sex, too much violence, or the wrong politics. He rips through the story chronologically and, sadly, with far too light a touch on facts and citations (and far too early to include anything from the contemporary horror era). He begins with Victorian crackdowns on nudie pictures and peep shows, and quickly catches up to Hollywood in 1926 with the Hayes Code. Horror comes onto the scene early, with The Cabinet of Dr Caligari targeted by some U.S. states for "portarying anarchy" and Tod Browning's Freaks "killed worldwide by censorship." The author touches on a smattering of other horror or horror-adjacent films, through the early 1970s.

Title: Knowing Animals
Author: Simmons, Laurence and Philip Armstrong
MLA 8 Citation: Simmons, Laurence and Philip Armstrong. Knowing Animals. Brill, 2007.
Horror Lex Summary: In her contribution in Chapter 3, noted psychoanalytic thinker and horror enthusiast Barbara Creed ponders the role of animals in cinema, particularly in horror, where she notes the boundary between "human" and "animal" often collapses. Going even further, Creed posits that horror often "depict[s] the screen animal in such a way that the viewer is compelled to raise questions about the anthropocentric nature of human society." King Kong (1933, 1976, 2005) is her prime example, offering "a dream of interspecies love and loss, desire and death."

Title: I Was a Cold War Monster: Horror Films, Eroticism, and the Cold War Imagination
Author: Hendershot, Cyndy
Original Publisher: Bowling Green State University Popular Press
MLA 8 Citation: Hendershot, Cyndy. I Was a Cold War Monster: Horror Films, Eroticism, and the Cold War Imagination. Bowling Green State U Popular Press, 2001.
Horror Lex Summary:
Hendershot specializes in sociological analysis of 1950s sci-fi and monster films, and I Was a Cold War Monster is her centerpiece book. Her focus is narrow: how does the philosophy of Georges Bataille explain the peculiar constellation of horror and thriller films that filled theaters in the post-WWII era? It would be too blithe to summarize her theory as "everything is about sex," but, well, monsters, body snatchers, vampires, and even teenagers are all about sex. But they are not simply metaphors for intercourse -- instead, they tap into the deep-rooted desires for both love and death that Bataille deemed "eroticism."

Each chapter unearths a different aspect of 1950s genre cinema and highlights seminal films. Hendershot takes on both the relatively obscure (such The Alligator People (1959)) and Hollywood blockbusters. For the latter, Hendershot voices clear dissent to popular interpretations that render the films too neat, such as the oft-heard statement that Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1956) is a rather flat metaphor for McCarthyism. While that is one reading, Hendershot takes the film instead to suggest that love and intimate comforts are the "means of countering the horror of a conformist society." Also compelling is her exposé of the shockingly misogynistic mother-blaming trend -- "Momism" -- that she ties to monstrous cinematic females.    

I Was a Cold War Monster does far more deep thinking about 1950s monster flicks than most critics have attempted. If there's a flaw here, it's that Hendershot puts out a lot of thoughts in a minimum of pages, so that each chapter's thesis seems a bit rushed and occasionally undersupported. In addition, without a working knowledge of Bataille's theories (which have notes of surrealism, psychoanalysis, and other schools), this may be a difficult read.

Title: Evolution and Popular Narrative
Author: Vanderbeke, Dirk and Brett Cooke (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Vanderbeke, Dirk, and Brett Cooke, editors. Evolution and Popular Narrative. Brill/Rodopi, 2019.
Horror Lex Summary:
In this volume regarding evolutionary themes in pop culture, frequent horror commentators Clasen and Platts take up the slasher subgenre, with particular focus on John Carpenter's Halloween (1978). The authors largely dismiss the oft-heard quip that slashers were merely a conservative political reaction to the free-wheeling 1960s/70s. Instead, they explain how slasher narratives (physical danger, stalking, male predator) and on-screen formal elements (point-of-view shots, focus on fear reactions) tap into our "evolved psychological machinery" to avoid physical harm, and are consequently perceived as engaging, arousing, even pleasurable.

In addition, David Andrews provides thoughts on 1970s rape-revenge films and their 21st-century remakes, and what they have to say about free will and the inevitable recourse to evolutionary strategies of behavior.
Films Discussed:
Clasen, Mathias and Todd K. Platts - Evolution and Slasher Films
・Halloween (1978)

Andrews, David - Remaking, or Not, the Classics: Straw Dogs and Biocultural Stability in Rape-Revenge Movies
・I Spit on Your Grave (1978)
・I Spit on Your Grave (2010)
・The Last House on the Left (1972)
・The Last House on the Left (2009)
・Straw Dogs (1971)
・Straw Dogs (2011)

Title: Bride of Frankenstein (BFI Film Classics Series)
Author: Manguel, Alberto
MLA 8 Citation: Manguel, Alberto. Bride of Frankenstein. British Film Institute, 1997.
Horror Lex Summary: Manguel relates a very personal connection to James Whale's beloved 1935 film, The Bride of Frankenstein, which he recalls watching as a child in the plush seats of a 1950s Buenos Aires theater. His book, part of the British Film Institute's Film Classics series, consists primarily of a close textual read of the film, plus his thoughts on creation myths and the figure of The Bride as a tragic figure of womanhood misused and sacrificed by men's folly, reflected not only in film, but also fine art. Manguel also includes background information on director James Whale, pre-production and production facts, and critical reception.

Horror Lex Summary: An encyclopedia of all things British in the cinema, including a chapter dedicated to horror. In his contribution, Ian Conrich surveys the world of British horror beginning with the earliest films, through the rise of the gothic and Hammer studios, sexploitation, and American influences. His essay is by design a shallow overview, with no films discussed in-depth. Yet Conrich takes moments to explore what makes horror such an innately British genre, reflecting a popular "fascination with morbidity" in times of social upheaval.

Title: Identifying Hollywood's Audiences: Cultural Identity and the Movies
Author: Stokes, Melvyn and Richard Maltby (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Stokes, Melvyn, and Richard Maltby, editors. Identifying Hollywood's Audiences: Cultural Identity and the Movies. British Film Institute, 1999.
Horror Lex Summary: Where would a movie be without its audience? Who actually paid to see this thing, anyway, and did they like it? These are questions answered by a series of authors in Stokes's and Maltby's book, from a variety of points of view -- psychology, economics, gender studies, even statistics. Skip Peter Kramer's sexist and astonishly ignorant chapter (in which he avers that women are offended by horror movies and don't go to them) and go straight to Brigid Cherry's essay on female horror audiences. Cherry explores the notion that women may enjoy horror films far more than previously reported, or exaggerate their feelings of fear or disgust when watching such films, in order to conform to expected gender norms. Her own research, a survey conducted with female horror fans, supports the idea that some women's love of horror is quite strong, and has simply been undetected.

Title: The Birds (BFI Film Classics Series)
Author: Paglia, Camille
MLA 8 Citation: Paglia, Camille. The Birds. 1998. 2nd ed., British Film Institute, 2020.
Horror Lex Summary:
Feminist scholar and author Camille Paglia analyzes Hitchock's "technically most difficult film," The Birds.Inspired by both a Daphne du Marier story and true-life news stories of unusual bird attacks, the director "directly addresses the theme of destructive, rapacious nature that was always implict in his fascination with crime." Paglia briefly touches upon the production of the film, but most of this slim, but packed, volume is dedicated to a scene-by scene analysis. No detail escapes Paglia's eye or imagination, starting with the opening titles (which, she notes, "overlap and disintegrate, as if bitten to pieces by invisible beaks"). 

Paglia's personality comes through strongly here, for better or for worse. That means phallic symbols are everywhere, from the heroine's clutch bag to pencils, and the themes of femininity/misogyny, captivity, and domestication are dominant in the film; both birds and women, she declares, are treated in the film as "a single category of capricious being." Paglia's style is conversational and uninterrupted by citations, as if she was sitting next to you, live-annotating the film. And while you may not care for her distracting tendency to make literary and film allusions out of sheer coincidences, there is no doubting her genuine love for Hitchcock's filmmaking.
Films Discussed:

Barbarella (1968)
The Birds (1963)

Title: Film/Genre
Author: Altman, Rick
MLA 8 Citation: Altman, Rick. Film/Genre. British Film Institute, 1999.
Horror Lex Summary: An influential volume regarding the definition and nature of the "genre" film, from Westerns to musicals to melodramas. Altman name-drops horror as a genre from time to time, but focuses on horror only in rare spots. He uses Creature from the Black Lagoon (1954) and other Universal monster movies as a case study of marketing across genres (horror and sci fi) to account for audiences' changing tastes; reviews the British history of censorship, particularly of the "video nasties"; addresses the genre concepts of "thrills" (referring to Frankenstein (1931)); and notes horror's Victorian dependence on monsters.
Films Discussed:
Creature from the Black Lagoon (1954)
Frankenstein (1931)

Horror Lex Summary: In his contribution to this compendium of essays on film audiences, horror scholar Mark Jancovich takes up Jonathan Demme's The Silence of the Lambs as a case study of the controversy of genre. Is Lambs a horror film, or is it a thriller? Is it simply too good to be a horror film? Jancovich looks at the contemporaneous reactions to the quality and content of the film by critics and filmgoers.

Title: Genre and Contemporary Hollywood
Author: Neale, Steve (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Neale, Stephen, editor. Genre and Contemporary Hollywood. British Film Institute, 2002.
Horror Lex Summary:
Neale, perhaps the foremost writer on film genre, brings together an impressive group of contributors in this volume, including a few who choose to focus on horror. 

Andrew Tudor -- in a sort of sequel to his 1989 book Monsters and Mad Scientists -- surveys the world of horror of the late 20th century and considers what makes it "postmodern." He finds that contemporary horror is still of the "paranoid" type, where authorities are helpless against the prevailing monster, which often arises from the bosom of the family. What sets these recent films apart is the deliberate, commercial use of reflexivity -- as in Scream, whose appeal was largely attributed to its delight in its own meta-horror. 

Dan Harries looks at parodic films that mock genres themselves, including horror. In fact, Harries asserts, horror is particularly ripe for parody, given that the genre rests on "suspense and thwarted expectations."

Austin Thomas uses Francis Ford Coppola's 1992 vampire epic as a case study in the careful packaging of genre. Through marketing emphasis on the prestige aspects of the picture and the erotic-romantic elements, producers aimed the movie at being as attractive as possible to as many viewers as possible, not just the core horror market, and to differentiate it from prior vampire flicks.
Films Discussed:
Tudor, Andrew - From Paranoia to Postmodernism? The Horror Movie in Late Modern Society

MLA 8 Citation: Wood, Jason. 100 Road Movies. British Film Institute, 2007.
Horror Lex Summary: A compendium of reviews for 100 films about road travel, sometimes literal, sometimes figurative. The horror genre is represented by Steven Spielberg's TV film Duel (which skillfully creates a "Kafkaesque world in which seemingly random and inescapable acts of psychological torture flourish and thrive"), Kathryn Bigelow's vampire flick Near Dark ("revolutionising the modern perception of vampires"), and Australian outback gore-fest Wolf Creek (which  "contemplat[es] with some distinction the question of how and why we relate to on-screen horror").
Films Discussed:
Duel (TV) (1971)
Near Dark (1987)
Wolf Creek (2005)

Title: The Italian Cinema Book
Author: Bondanella, Peter (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Bondanella, Peter, editor. The Italian Cinema Book. British Film Institute, 2014.
Horror Lex Summary: In Peter Bondanella's sweeping survey of Italian film, giallo expert Mikal J. Koven pens a chapter on the Italian horror genre, starting with I vampiri and moving through the gialli and slashers of the 1960s-1980s, cannibals, zombies, Nazis, and post-apocalyptic nightmares, with commentary on Italy's unique trend-based film system. In her contribution, Mary P. Wood doubles down on the Bava love with an essay reviewing his filmography and tracing his influence through modern day.

Title: Meanings of Ripley: The Alien Quadrilogy and Gender
Author: Graham, Elizabeth (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Graham, Elizabeth, editor. Meanings of Ripley: The Alien Quadrilogy and Gender. Cambridge Scholars, 2010.
Horror Lex Summary:
Editor Graham presents a series of essays addressing one of the most iconic heroines of horror/science fiction films: Ellen Ripley of the Alien franchise. Famously, the role of Ripley was not written for a woman. But after being cast with Sigourney Weaver, who dedicated herself to the role over the course of four films and almost two decades, the figure of Ripley took on not just the weight of sci-fi stardom but also great interest as a trailblazing female character. Graham's intent is to facilitate an inter-disciplinary discussion of Ripley as woman, at a level suitable for undergraduates. (The volume is, for the most part, as jargon-free as advertised.)

Each of the five chapters takes on a different aspect of Ripley and the question of gender. Chapter 1 is a fine starting point; author Moore maps Ripley from the original Alien onto the advent of second-wave feminism and its radical wing. In Chapter 2, author Wood turns to its sequel Aliens, with a depressingly accurate report on the undoing of Alien's incipient feminism, and the "sexist ideology that encases" the second film. Chapter 3 (author Dadlez) analyzes Alien3 in the context of Simon de Beauvoir's feminist manifesto The Second Sex, comparing Ripley to Eve, a destroyer of the male status quo who becomes the "mediatrix" of both damnation and salvation. In Chapter 4, authors Bach and Langer catalog the many incidents of sexualized violence in the series and note that, through the series, Ripley gains the ability to defend against such violence as a hybrid creature -- part synthetic/human, part man/woman. Finally, in Chapter 5, author and editor Graham considers whether Ripley has attained the philosophical status of autonomous being, and whether the very concept of autonomy is rigged game in that it is gendered male.

At the back of the book are scene-by-scene recaps of the  Alien quadrilogy films, which, helpfully, show departures from theatrical and special editions, plus a (largely unnecessary) drive-by view of the Predator and Alien v. Predator franchises.
Films Discussed:
Alien (1979)
Alien3 (1992)
Alien: Resurrection (1997)
Aliens (1986)
Tags: Ellen Ripley, mother, motherhood, child, children, kids, feminism, women, gender, female, rape, aliens, psychoanalysis, Freud

Title: Violence in the Arts: Illustrated Edition (original title: Violence in the Arts)
Author: Fraser, John
MLA 8 Citation: Fraser, John. Violence in the Arts: Illustrated Edition. 1974. Cambridge UP, 1976.
Horror Lex Summary:
Despite its title, Violence in the Arts is not a sociological treatise or an examination of the evils of violent entertainment. It is a personal essay, as author Fraser announces in his introduction, about the meaning of aggression, monsters, and victimhood in popular culture within the psyche of the post-WWII population that had just learned a harsh lesson of what violence is. 

The book is segregated roughly into sections: "Ambivalences," in which Fraser considers what violence we adore and what violence we abhor; "Revolt," regarding the politics of violence; Victims; and Violators. Fraser fluidly moves through a remarkable range of references, from the Marquis de Sade to Herschell Gordon Lewis to Shakespeare, and he finds connections that even those who are well-read may not have noticed. 

Fraser addresses horror only occasionally, most notably in the section regarding "Violators." He notes the symbolic importance of a new breed of horror villains, such as Dr. Genessier of Les yeux sans visage, who show bottomless capacity for evil, yet are not deformed by it as they may have been in the classic horror era. Instead, "they are capable of functioning perfectly successfully in normal society" -- reminiscent of Nazis, the Manson clan, and any number of modern antagonists.

In a sea of heavily footnoted, clinical dissections of popular culture, Fraser's personal and conversational approach is refreshing. While his references are stuck in a midcentury framework, Violence in the Arts remains oft-quoted and a meaningful work even for contemporary audiences.

Title: Italian Film
Author: Landy, Marcia
MLA 8 Citation: Landy, Marcia. Italian Film. Cambridge UP, 2000.
Horror Lex Summary: Horror and the giallo are largely ignored in Marcia Landy's tome on Italian national cinema, except for several pages on Dario Argento's Profondo rosso (1975). She identifies it as a reluctant horror progenitor, a film that "seems more interested in investigating the visual medium" -- with its baroque camerawork and "highly choreographed visual detail" -- "than in gratuitous images of violence."
Films Discussed: Deep Red (Profondo rosso) (1975)

Title: Beyond Aesthetics: Philosophical Essays
Author: Carroll, Noël
MLA 8 Citation: Carroll, Noël. Beyond Aesthetics: Philosophical Essays. Cambridge UP, 2001.
Horror Lex Summary: In this series of essays, philosopher Carroll ponders the connection between art and its inherent aesthetics -- primarily to discount that connection as the dividing line between artistic and non-artistic expression, and instead look to author's intent, emotional, and even moral responses. In the section "Horror and Humor," he takes up the case of the horror-comedy film: why is it that something that should elicit both laughs and gasps appeal to audiences, rather than dissolving into contradiction? To answer the question, Carroll dives into the nature of art-horror and incongruity as a basis of humor.

Title: Myth, Mind and the Screen: Understanding the heroes of our time
Author: Izod, John
MLA 8 Citation: Izod, John. Myth, Mind and the Screen: Understanding the heroes of our time. Cambridge UP, 2001.
Horror Lex Summary: In Chapter 6 of his book examining popular culture through Jungian analysis, author John Izod looks to 1991's The Silence of the Lambs and the hero arc of its protagonist, Clarice Starling (Jodie Foster). While much of Starling's personal growth is typical of the hero myth -- she has her own monster to slay, in the form of Hannibal Lecter -- Izod notes how her journey is uniquely informed by her gender. Starling's challenge lies in being "a young woman who has hitherto suppressed her own feelings in order to comply with male value systems," and "her awakening brings knowledge of her own female powers, of which she was previously not fully aware."
Films Discussed:
Chapter 6: The quest of a female hero - The Silence of the Lambs
・The Silence of the Lambs (1991)

Title:
Recycled Culture in Contemporary Art and Film:
The Uses of Nostalgia
Author: Dika, Vera
MLA 8 Citation:
Dika, Vera. Recycled Culture in Contemporary Art and Film:
The Uses of Nostalgia. Cambridge UP, 2003.
Horror Lex Summary:
Dika examines artistic reuses of past images, plots, and styles, such as the painstaking pastiches of bygone eras in nostalgia films like American Graffiti. She looks closely at The Texas Chain Saw Massacre, a study in past-present contrasts. The film is carefully imbued with a look of documentary-style realism, but that realism is entirely fake. It also incorporates elements of the Western genre, but transports the viewer from an idyllic, lightly sun-toasted version of Texas to the post-Vietnam version, in which the entire film acts as a "physical, aural, and visual attack on the viewer." (Dika also suggests that Texas Chain Saw intentionally hearkens back to Psycho as its ur-text, which is arguably little more then genre-coincidence.) 

Later, Dika addresses the "stalker film" (e.g., Halloween) which she claims "owes more to the science fiction films of the 1950s and to the Western than it does to Psycho." On this point, she analyzes Scream and its self-reflexive attitude, as well as Gus van Sant's remake of Psycho. Fair warning, this is a dense academic text full of film theory jargon, and not for the casual reader.
Films Discussed:
Apocalypse Now (1979)
Halloween (1978)
The Last Temptation of Christ (1988)
Psycho (1960)
Psycho (1998)
The Rocky Horror Picture Show (1975)
Scream (1996)
The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (1974)
The Thing From Another World (1951)

Title: Horror Film and Psychoanalysis: Freud's Worst Nightmare
Author: Schneider, Steven Jay (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Schneider, Steven Jay, editor. Horror Film and Psychoanalysis: Freud's Worst Nightmare. 2004. Cambridge UP, 2009.
Horror Lex Summary:
In his introduction, editor and noted horror academic Schneider explains that this volume is not intended to merely put forth a new psychoanalytic view of horror movies, but explain what it means to have a psychoanalytic theory of horror movies, in an attempt to harmonize competing theories. A worthy goal, given the volume and outsized influence of writers coming at horror genre from a psychoanalytic direction since the 1970s -- Mulvey, Creed, Clover, Williams, and more.

The foreword, written by renowned movie critic and self-described Marxist Robin Wood, is an important starting point. Wood explains that for himself and his contemporaries, horror movies were important because their ideas were important. Their nihilism and progressiveness laid bare social ills and repressive mores. Psychoanalysis, Wood writes, "was a valuable weapon that could be used politically."

This volume is intensely academic, so fair warning that it's likely most enjoyed by those of the same bent. Most accessible are: Schneider's essay (Chapter 6), in which he creates a taxonomy of the "cinematic double," even if he was rude enough to invite author Cynthia Freeland to contribute a similar theory in Chapter 5 and then proceed to pick it apart; Harvey Roy Greenberg's essay regarding the "rehabilitation" of monsters in film through comedy, proximity to children, and general sympathy (Chapter 7); the always-entertaining Barbara Creed with her fantasy of Freud contemplating modern horror cinema, and in particular, Dr. Hannibal Lecter (Chapter 11); and Linda Badley's examination of the horror director as auteur (Chapter 13).

Title: An Illustrated History of Horror and Science-Fiction Films: The Classic Era, 1895-1967 (original title: An Illustrated History of the Horror Film)
Author: Clarens, Carlos
MLA 8 Citation: Clarens, Carlos. An Illustrated History of Horror and Science-Fiction Films: The Classic Era, 1895-1967. 1967. Revised ed., Da Capo, 1997.
Horror Lex Summary:
Long considered a seminal text on horror film, Clarens's An Illustrated History is unquestionably outdated 50+ years later, but still a wonderful time capsule. In 1967, no "serious" writers wrote about the horror genre, nor was it considered historically relevant - in fact, as Clarens notes, "horror movies have been called all kinds of names, running from incitement to crime to psychopathy of the masses." Here, Clarens reclaims horror as worthy: "Fantastic art, of which horror films and science fiction are the popoular champions, makes us realize that man carries in himself an instinct for destruction, but also the will to curb this instinct."

Clarens's book takes readers from the earliest days of silent horror films through the mid-1960s, and he includes films in the fantastic and sci-fi genres. Essentially a filmography with commentary, Clarens writes fluidly from film to film in roughly chronological order, offering historical notes, critical readings, and frank, often entertaining opinions (such as his take on I Was a Teenage Frankenstein as "inspiredly absurd" and his dis of Roger Corman's Masque of the Red Death as having "all the flat undimensioned elegance of a well-drawn comic strip"). He also shows an international reach uncharacteristic for a midcentury writer, for example, lauding the 1963 Czech film Ikarie XB1 and highlighting Mexico's horror tradition.

Note, however, that it is a tad misleading to call this an "illustrated" guide - aside from a few pages of black-and-white photos in the first and last pages, there are no illustrations. An index of the films, plus cast and credits, are included in the back.

Title: Carrie (Studies in the Horror Film Series)
Author: Aisenberg, Joe
MLA 8 Citation: Aisenberg, Joe. Carrie. Centipede, 2012.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Each book in Centipede Press's Studies in the Horror Film series focuses on one seminal horror film, written by a guest author.)

Fans could hardly want a fiercer defense of Brian De Palma's Carrie, the director's "first fully sustained masterpiece of theme as style…an allusive postmodern nightmare and a universal fairy tale about growing up different." Author Aisenberg provides background to the film, from Carrie White's genesis in Stephen King's 1973 novel (and all the gender-based conflict its writing may or may not have created in King's psyche), casting, and production. He then moves to a deep, textual read, liberally interwoven with screenplay notes, DVD commentary, and interviews to explain scenes and camera shots. His attention to detail helps brings alive certain aspects of the movie one might have overlooked, such as the brief moment in which Carrie is locked inside the prayer closet by her mother and contemplates a creepy crucifixation statue, which, we learn, was conceived of by De Palma and realized in painstaking detail by art director Fisk (and presages Margaret White's death scene). 

Aisenberg's approach is more about film-making than larger ideas of the film's interpretation, but as a textual guide, it's arguably definitive. As a bonus, the author incudes his own 2009 interview with De Palma which, unfortunately, contains more of Aisenberg's thoughts than  De Palma's (at one point, he tells Aisenberg "You know more about this than I do"), and another interview with screenwriter Lawrence D. Cohen.

Title: The Golden Age of "B" Movies
Author: McClelland, Doug
MLA 8 Citation: McClelland, Doug. The Golden Age of "B" Movies. 1978. Bonanza Books, 1981.
Horror Lex Summary:
A collection of reviews for 50 lesser-known, cheapie films of the "Golden Age" -- which the author defines de facto as the early-mid 1940s -- when movies could be on the verger of tawdry, but there was as yet no "exploitation" sensibility. Most of these films would today be considered thrillers or film noir, although were often marketed as horror.

The volume begins with a charming yet discomforting essay by actress Evelyn Ankers (Gwen in The Wolf Man, and many other films). She breezes through stories of her career in horror films, incuding having to hide her pregnancy, endure crew insults, and fight off attempted sexual assault, with the light tone of one recalling memories of a summer picnic. While one applauds her resiliency, by getting this sort of insight into the real world of 1940s Hollywood, one also might wonder what was so "golden" about this age after all.
