Title: Chain Saw Confidential: How We Made the World's Most Notorious Horror Movie
Author: Hansen, Gunnar
MLA 8 Citation: Hansen, Gunnar. Chain Saw Confidential: How We Made the World's Most Notorious Horror Movie. Chronicle Books, 2013.
Horror Lex Summary: Before he died far too young, Gunnar Hansen -- Leatherface in the original Texas Chain Saw Massacre -- thankfully saw fit to write his memoirs of the film.  Many of the details have been recited elsewhere (the heat, the smell, the animal parts strewn everywhere), but getting Hansen's personal account is invaluable. With a refreshingly ego-free writing style, he freely reminiscences about interactions with the cast and the tin-can-and-a-shoestring production, e.g., his confession that they used a working chain saw during the infamous scene in which Leatherface chops up character Kirk; actor Bill Vail says "I could feel splinters hitting me, I could feel the hot oil coming off the blade...". Also compelling is Hansen's discussion of Leatherface's psyche and sexuality, and his account of the money squabbles that arose after the film wrapped, thanks to a mobbed-up distributor. In the end, the book reveals that Hansen is an undercover Rennaissance man, and serves as a fine tribute.
Films Discussed: The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (1974)

Title: The Bad Guys: A Pictorial History of the Movie Villain
Author: Everson, William K.
MLA 8 Citation: Everson, William K. The Bad Guys: A Pictorial History of the Movie Villain. Citadel Press, 1964.
Horror Lex Summary: Everson, a frequent writer on the horror film, assembled this frothy and photo-laden book about cinematic antagonists of all kinds, whether human, beast, or alien. In his section "The Monsters," the author briefly hits all the horror classics - Frankenstein, Dracula, King Kong. In "The Psychos," he adds "Freudian" baddies such as Norman Bates and in "Mad Doctors and Mad Killers," the evil geniuses like Dr. Pretorius from Bride of Frankenstein. Best for those looking for a fun flip-through book on classic and midcentury films, rather than content.

Title: Hollywood From Vietnam to Reagan…and Beyond (original title: Hollywood From Vietnam to Reagan)
Author: Wood, Robin
MLA 8 Citation: Wood, Robin. Hollywood From Vietnam to Reagan…and Beyond. 1986. Revised ed., Columbia UP, 2003.
Horror Lex Summary:
Prolific, controversial film critic Wood collects his thoughts on popular cinema from the 1970s and 1980s. Those familiar with Wood understand that he is not a critic in the style of Roger Ebert or Pauline Kael; he examines films not only for their entertainment value and contributions to film as an art form, but also for their political consciousness. Specifically, this means declaring whether a film is on the correct side of Wood's strict leftist-Marxist-Freudian-feminist-bisexual outlook, one far more radical than 21st century readers are accustomed to seeing in mainstream movie critique. 

Wood famously had a soft spot for horror because he believed that the genre was particularly conducive to rooting out regressive tendencies and displaying the evils of late capitalist, patriarchal society. His essay included here as Chapter 5, "The American Nightmare: Horror in the 70s," is his seminal piece on the topic. He is an unabashed fan of George A. Romero's and Larry Cohen's films (Chapter 6, 14) and perpetually conflicted about Brian De Palma's (Chapter 7). In the latter, Wood lauds Sisters (1972) for being one of the preeminent movies of the 1970s, but works through discomfort over the director's treatment of women in others. In Chapters 8 and 9, he cannot disguise his disgust at the evolving state of Hollywood in the early 1980s. He bemoans the "false, manufactured optimism" of the time and the popularity of return-to-childhood fare -- including the massively popular Star Wars series, E.T., and slashers -- and dismisses the entire age as a massive step backward in terms of both politics and cinema.

Title: Laughing Screaming: Modern Hollywood Horror and Comedy
Author: Paul, William
MLA 8 Citation: Paul, William. Laughing Screaming: Modern Hollywood Horror and Comedy. Columbia UP, 1994.
Horror Lex Summary:
From the title, one would think this book is about horror comedies. More accurate to say the book is about horror and comedy, two genres whose attractiveness often lies in their vulgarity. 

In his first several (rather dry) chapters, Paul addresses "gross out" entertainment from an art history perspective, arguing that vulgarity serves an important cultural function as an expression of liberation that cannot be contained by morality or even reality -- like riding on a roller coaster, which prompts both laughs and screams. This is precisely why certain "beats" of comedy are recognizable in horror films, and vice versa (think of the final shock scene A Nightmare on Elm Street). 

Paul locates the vulgarity in horror in several respects. Blood and guts, of course -- but it must be gratuitous to be vulgar. He also examines the use of children in horror films as victims or monsters, which precedes the corruption of families (Night of the Living Dead, The Bad Seed, The Exorcist). As Paul points out, the increased "gross physicality" of horror in the 1970s led to the body itself becoming a locus of vulgarity, such as in Carrie (soaked in both menstral and pig's blood), The Brood (in which the antagonist literally turns herself inside out), and Alien.

Title: Attack of the Leading Ladies: Gender, Sexuality, and Spectatorship in Classic Horror Cinema
Author: Berenstein, Rhona J.
MLA 8 Citation: Berenstein, Rhona J. Attack of the Leading Ladies: Gender, Sexuality, and Spectatorship in Classic Horror Cinema. 1996. Columbia UP, 2018.
Horror Lex Summary:
Author Berenstein "interrogat[es] popular assumptions about horror's representations of gender" -- an abitious task -- using classic horror cinema of the 1930s as her study set. 

First, she challenges the common view of the horror film as enforcing traditional sexuality and gender roles, both in the characters and spectators. Monsters are fluid, she notes. Even if coded as male/female, monsters are not truly men/women or heterosexual; think of Count Dracula's inhumanity and his homoerotic effect on Jonathan Harker. That fluidity gives permission to spectators, too, to enjoy the slide into what the author calls "drag." Berenstein also challenges the notion that female victims in "hypnosis" monster films (Dracula et al) is solely an exercise in women's masochism; explores the homoerotic and homosocial properties of mad-doctor movies; and unpacks the role of white females in "jungle films" such as King Kong. 

This is a truly academic work, stemming from Berenstein's PhD thesis. So there's a lot of inside-baseball here, and you'll get more out this text if you first bone up on the seminal texts by Carroll, Mulvey, Twitchell, and Clover around which Berenstein structures her arguments.

Title: Shocking Representation: Historical Trauma, National Cinema, and the Modern Horror Film
Author: Lowenstein, Adam
MLA 8 Citation: Lowenstein, Adam. Shocking Representation: Historical Trauma, National Cinema, and the Modern Horror Film. Columbia UP, 2005.
Horror Lex Summary:
While many writers have theorized that horror movies reflect societal anxieties, Lowenstein goes one step further: they reflect "wounds in the fabric of culture and history" caused by war and national tragedy that "bleed through conventional confines of time and space." In Shocking Representation, he draws upon trauma studies as well as art and film theory to explore the culturally relevant connection between trauma, mourning, and some of our most important horror fictions.

Lowenstein's thesis takes him on a trip around the world and through several decades of the 20th and 21st centuries. World War II, however, is the dominant theme. He interprets Georges Franju's Eyes Without a Face (Les Yeux Sans Visage) (1960) as a film heavy with French guilt over the WWII Vichy occupation era and the war in Algeria. As for England, he looks to Peeping Tom (1960) as a reflection of the breakdown of class boundaries after WWII, hailed as "The People's War," but whose unifying nature could not be sustained in the decades after. Moving to Japan, the author reads Onibaba (1964) as an allegory for the Hiroshima bombing and war victimhood, tied up in the figure of haunted women. 

The chapter on Wes Craven's The Last House on the Left (1972) moves to a different war, different era: Vietnam. As Lowenstein demonstrates, the film confronts the divisiveness of the era, in which American society learned to take sides by demonizing the opposition -- young/old, hippie/conservative, blue collar/white collar -- crystallized into both jungle combat and home-grown violent tragedies like the Kent State shooting. 

Lowenstein wraps up with a chapter on David Cronenberg, whose films literalize the fractured nature of national (specifically, Canadian) identity through fractured bodies, and a brief final note on 9/11.

While Lowenstein is an engaging writer, the concepts he draws from -- grounded in philosophy, psychoanalysis, history, and film theory -- are difficult to grasp with a mere breezy read. The book is also bursting at the seams with historical references and primary sources. As one of the best books available linking horror to history, it may be worth multiple reads.

Title: Hideous Progeny: Disability, Eugenics, and Classic Horror Cinema
Author: Smith, Angela M.
MLA 8 Citation: Smith, Angela M. Hideous Progeny: Disability, Eugenics, and Classic Horror Cinema. Columbia UP, 2012.
Horror Lex Summary:
From where in our collective psyche did classic monsters come? The ravages of war, some say. Ancient myths, others say. Smith has a different idea: that the monsters of early horror cinema looked the way they did and got the reactions that they did, at least in part, because of an early concept of body horror: the fear of disability. The driving force of the eugenics movement of the late 19th and early 20th centuries was to identify and support the genetically superior while diagnosing and suppressing - if not outright killing - the genetically inferior. When the broken and grotesque Frankenstein's monster towered over the body of the young white girl, or Dracula appears in Lucy's bedchamber as a bat intending to mix their blood, he is precisely the type of degenerate "Other" that politicians and moralizers warned those girls against marrying. And ironically, these films about degenerates often became shunned themselves as degenerate films (think Freaks).

Smith makes a good case that physical disability has been overlooked as one of the "differences" encoded in the dread of horror. Her academic tone is sometimes a bit of a sludge, but her thesis is unique and worth the read.

Title: Screening Torture: Media Representations of State Terror and Political Domination
Author: Flynn, Michael and Fabiola Fernandez Salek (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Flynn, Michael, and Fabiola Fernandez Salek, editors. Screening Torture: Media Representations of State Terror and Political Domination. Columbia UP, 2012.
Horror Lex Summary:
Editors Flynn and Salek and their contributors take on the rise of torture depictions in films and TV, primarily in political and action thrillers. While cinematic torture is not strictly a post-9/11 phenomenon, certainly the 9/11 terrorist attacks and the ensuing international debate about how far a nation may go to avenge or investigate such crimes (see the Abu Graib scandal) brought the issue to the forefront. Each chapter examines one facet of the torture debate, often through the lens of pop culture. 

Be forewarned, however, this book is far more about history, politics, and morality than it is about horror, and there is no in-depth discussion of so-called "torture porn" of Hostel or Saw. Most relevant to the horror genre is Chapter 5, on Peeping Tom and the "predatory force" of the camera.

Title: The Teenage Slasher Movie Book (original title: Teenage Wasteland: The Slasher Movie Uncut)
Author: Kerswell, J.A.
MLA 8 Citation: Kerswell, J.A. The Teenage Slasher Movie Book. 2010. 2nd ed., CompanionHouse, 2018.
Horror Lex Summary: There is perhaps no one on Earth more knowledgeable about the subject of slashers than author J.A. (Justin) Kerswell, who keeps up the Hysteria Lives website, with its exhaustive series of slasher reviews and bonus content, and its companion, the long-running podcast (and Horror Lex favorite) Hysteria Continues. This book is the breezy, colorful, coffee-table version of the slasher encyclopedia that Kerswell could write. The book gives a basic overview of slasher movie origins, gialli, the late '70s-early '80s boom and then rapid bust, the undying sequels and remakes, and the subgenre's revival via Scream and beyond. It's a basic education for those not well-versed in slashers, and a trophy book for those who are.

Title: Blood Money: A History of the First Teen Slasher Film Cycle
Author: Nowell, Richard
MLA 8 Citation: Newell, Richard. Blood Money: A History of the First Teen Slasher Film Cycle. Continuum, 2011.
Horror Lex Summary:
Refreshingly, Blood Money is not a review book or a nostalgia piece, but a historical record of a well-loved and much-misunderstood film era: the teen slasher boom of the late '70s to early '80s. Author Nowell examines this not from an artistic perspective, but as a business phenomenon, through production, distribution, and promotion by the major Hollywood studios and indies. Along the way, he provides (in his words) a new model of film cycle development, from the Pioneer Production (Black Christmas) to Carpetbagger Cash-Ins (Happy Birthday To Me, Graduation Day, et al). 

While his diagrammatical approach to the structure of the slasher era is perhaps needlessly literal, Nowell truly shines when offering observations about the subgenre that buck decades of conventional wisdom. Hollywood tastemakers, he posits, “actually went to extraordinary lengths to make early teen slashers attractive to female youth, to minimize displays of violence, gore, and suffering, and to invite comparisons to a wide range of post-classical Hollywood’s biggest hits....” In fact, many slashers could better be described as “female-centered animal comedy-infused murder-mysteries,” with the intent of garnering the allowance money of the same young women (and their dates) who went to see Saturday Night Fever. Nowell ably supports his thesis with a special examination of Halloween and Friday the 13th, both big hits, taking different paths; Prom Night, a Canadian film built to break into the U.S. market; and the "Group of 11" slashers from 1981 that signaled oversupply and a (temporary) end of the trend. 

Surprises abound in the book, such as Nowell's provocative opinion that Black Christmas owes more to Magnum Force than any proto-slasher like Psycho; his proof that Halloween's financial success is overblown; and a fun comparison of movie posters, showing how one film evoked another with simple images. While Nowell's book can be faulted for its density and repetition, slasher fans should feel free to treat it like a Bible.

Title: New American Teenagers: The Lost Generation of Youth in 1970s Film
Author: Brickman, Barbara Jane
MLA 8 Citation: Brickman, Barbara Jane. New American Teenagers: The Lost Generation of Youth in 1970s Film. Continuum, 2012.
Horror Lex Summary:
Brickman brings as new perspective to the (admittedly scant) literature on teenage culture as depicted in film. Her thesis is that whereas teen flicks of the '50s and '60s were unremittingly "straight" -- with narratives that steered teens headlong into "compliant, gendered, heterosexual, middle class" society -- films of the '70s provided a limited reprieve. During our late mid-century American "crisis of confidence," teens on screen were allowed to challenge moral and gender norms as well as show a "chilling disregard for the authority of parents, or more specifically patriarchal, culture." 

Brickman examines this trend in different strains of 1970s films that either depicted or were marketed toward teenagers: the high-school-centered movie, either in fact (Grease) or in spirit (The Rocky Horror Picture Show); coming-of-age films (Badlands, American Graffitti); works reflecting a new appreciation of "the queer kid" (An American Family, Ode to Billy Joe); the films of Jodie Foster, Disney's wholesome androgyne (Freaky Friday); and teen slashers (Halloween). 

In this final chapter ("Brothers, Sisters, and Chainsaws: Sibling Rivalry and Peer Centrality in the Teen Slasher Film"), Brickman examines the relationship between siblings in slashers. Speaking from a primarily psychoanalytic viewpoint, Brickman asserts that slashers depict a clash of adolescents -- the sexually stunted boogeyman versus the adrogynous Final Girl -- which reflects a lateral, "sibling rivalry" rather than a rift between generations. This theme, Brickman argues, shows up in the Sally/Franklin and Sawyer Family strife of Texas Chain Saw Massacre and the sororicidal Michael Myers and his sister-target, Laurie Strode. Given that one's sibling is essentially a replacement (the same genetic package in another's body), these films reflect a repressed "desire to kill the other whose existence threatens to annihilate you," which, at the same time, threatens murder of the self.

Title: Post-9/11 Horror in American Cinema
Author: Wetmore, Kevin J.
MLA 8 Citation: Wetmore, Kevin J. Post-9/11 Horror in American Cinema. Continuum, 2012.
Horror Lex Summary:
Author Wetmore tackles the still-raw subject of the 9/11 terrorist attacks and the deep wounds they have left on our collective psyche. Horror cinema, he offers, is an art form that has absorbed that trauma and reflects it back. Sometimes this is quite literal, as with the spate of post-9/11 New-York-destruction films in which planes crash, bodies fall from buildings, and the camera shakes as everyone, even the camera operator, runs away from danger (Cloverfield, War of the Worlds). 

Other scars can be traced in more subtle ways, Wetmore notes. After 9/11, horror movie deaths become more random and endings much bleaker, reflecting our inability to stop the carnage; see The Mist, in which no amount of stockpiling dog food against the grocery store windows was enough to keep people safe. Ghosts and vampires became more malevolent, and a new preoccupation with religious fundamentalism brought on a new wave of exorcism films, in which demons are real and must be fought. The same happened to zombies, who brought on apocalypses that politicians and even the military were incapable of stopping. Revenge in the form of torture became fully justified (Hostel, I Spit on Your Grave (2010)). 

Finally, Wetmore notes the many remakes of '80s slashers that populated screens in the 2000s, which he believes can be at least partially explained by nostalgia for an earlier time, when America was strong and a killer's rationale could be summed up with one word: "evil." A well-organized and thoughtful book.

Title: Wasteland: The Great War and the Origins of Modern Horror
Author: Poole, W. Scott
MLA 8 Citation: Poole, W. Scott. Wasteland: The Great War and the Origins of Modern Horror. Counterpoint, 2018.
Horror Lex Summary:
Author Poole draws a direct line between the atrocities of World War I -- of a type and scale never before seen in human history -- and the big screen horrors that followed. Both soldiers and the civilian wartime homefront were covered in "viscera, mud, and blood" and involuntarily confronted with "millions of corpses that could not be buried." Poison gas, mutilations, mass death; these horrors became known even to the privileged and previously optimistic. Enter the bloodsuckers and the living dead, who found willing audiences with a new-found fascination with body horror.

Poole surveys the biggest horror film hits of the '20s and '30s, along with rarer European cuts, to make his case, and includes well-researched accounts of the personal relationships between individual artists of the time -- actors, directors, writers, painters -- and the war. Most enlightening is Poole's distinction between the postwar, deeply traumitized Europeans on the road to Nazism (who gravitated toward the dark and authoritarian; Caligari) and the cheerfully deluded Americans (who preferred to "mix scares and giggles").

Title: Cult Movies: The Classics, the Sleepers, the Weird, and the Wonderful
Author: Peary, Danny
MLA 8 Citation: Pear, Danny. Cult Movies: The Classics, the Sleepers, the Weird, and the Wonderful. 1981. Gramercy Books, 1998.
Horror Lex Summary:
"Cultists don't merely enjoy their favorite films," writes Peary, "they worship them." With that, Peary, a film critic and writer with an unparalleled reputation for spotting diamonds in the rough, offers his first collection of recommended cult films -- those that appeal not to the masses, he explains, but to a minority of devotees, and on a pedigree of plots, dialogue, and characters outside the Hollywood mainstream. (You may quibble with this definition, given Peary's selections; Citizen Kane and Casablanca are both here.) 

In this volume, Peary highlights 105 films, a portion of which can be considered fully or partially within the horror genre. For each, he provides basic film facts, a thorough synopsis, and an essay commenting on its place in film history. Peary's style is conversational and anti-academic, but he is supremely well-informed on film and pulls no punches (e.g., "The Brood is...Cronenberg's one good film.") While dated, this is still an entertaining book to peruse if you put on your 1981 glasses.

Title: The Phantom's Ultimate Video Guide
Author: The Phantom of the Movies (Joe Kane)
MLA 8 Citation: The Phantom of the Movies. The Phantom's Ultimate Video Guide. Dell, 1989.
Horror Lex Summary:
In 1993, Joe Kane, as his alter ego The Phantom of the Movies, started a quarterly newsletter -- VideoScope -- dedicated to genre films released on home video. (It's still around in print magazine form, check out https://videoscopemag.com.) At the time, the right movie in the right format and the right version could be devilishly difficult to track down. Kane had thus started scratching an itch many fans didn't even know they had. 

VideoScope's popularity spawned this reference guide, which contains brief reviews of over 1,000 films in the genres of action, horror, sci fi, mystery, cult, westerns, and more. In the back of the book, Kane also includes information on the video label availability of each title, plus mail-order and other specialty video suppliers. A gem for those nostalgic for the pre-streaming days.
Films Discussed: Too many to list - check out the free copy noted above.

Title: Scare Tactics: The Art, Craft, and Trade Secrets of Writing, Producing, and Directing Chillers and Thrillers
Author: Russo, John
MLA 8 Citation: Russo, John. Scare Tactics: The Art, Craft, and Trade Secrets of Writing, Producing, and Directing Chillers and Thrillers. Dell, 1992.
Horror Lex Summary:
A how-to book for those looking to create their own genre pictures, from developing the storyline to filming to selling it. Russo, a writer/director/producer known for several hits (Night of the Living Dead) and misses (The Majorettes) gives his best advice, albeit about an indie scene that no longer exists. 

The book is most enlightening for Russo's trivia-laden asides on which films really nailed either a "do" or "don't" in terms of good filmmaking, such as the chapters in which he painstakingly teases out every element of his screenplay for Voodoo Dawn (1990). Romero fans will also appreciate the detailed tidbits on Night of the Living Dead (which Russo wrote). The big drawback, of course, is that by the end of the book, you've probably learned far more about Russo's career than your own.

In the back of the book, Russo presents interviews from five influential members of the horror filmmaking world -- Wes Craven, Clive Barker, Joe Dante, John Landis, and Rick Baker -- who talk about their craft and biggest films.

Title: Halloween: The History of American's Darkest Holiday
Author: Skal, David J.
MLA 8 Citation: Skal, David J. Halloween: The History of American's Darkest Holiday. Dover, 2016.
Horror Lex Summary: In Chapter 5 of his ode to All Hallow's Eve ("Halloween on Screen") horror-movie historian Skal traces the oddly sparse history of movie and television depictions of the holiday prior to John Carpenter's seminal film. Halloween (1978) -- "a truly iconic film" -- is lovingly detailed and identified as the true root of the slasher boom then to come, notwithstanding the earlier influence of Psycho. Most notable, however, is Skal's attention to Halloween II and the alleged link between that film and two real-life murders in California, which resulted in a showing of the film in court, "the first time in U.S. legal history that a commercial motion picture had been submitted as evidence at a murder trial." Skal bravely marches through the remaining sequels, remarking upon The Shape's transformation from phantom menace to "perverse Christ figure" and intelligently replying to accusations of misogyny. A fresh take on the entire series.

Title: Skin Shows: Gothic Horror and the Technology of Monsters
Author: Halberstam, Judith (Jack)
MLA 8 Citation: Halberstam, Judith (Jack). Skin Shows: Gothic Horror and the Technology of Monsters. Duke UP, 1995.
Horror Lex Summary:
Monsters are not necessarily hulking, deformed creatures, Halberstam notes. Sometimes the difference between the monstrous and the normal is only skin deep -- the metaphor that the author has based this book upon.

It is difficult to describe what Skin Shows is "about," given Halberstam's elliptical style and generous use of academic and cultural references. In brief, Halberstam uses a small selection of literary and cinematic works to explore how our culture makes a monster, wrapped up with all our notions of race, nationality, gender, religion, and sexuality that render the monster a "meaning machine." Horror movies, by moving the monster front-and-center, disrupt the dominant culture's boundaries.

Halberstam highlights one major work per chapter, starting with Mary Shelley's Frankenstein, which is more about the construction of humans than of monsters, and Bram Stoker's Dracula, in which the author reads the titular vampire as a multifactorial Other -- a pan-gendered, pan-sexual Jew. She considers two tales of gothic doubling and buried sexuality, Oscar Wilde's The Picture of Dorian Gray and Robert Louis Stevenson's Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. Film is the focus of the final three chapters. She finds an arguable feminist psychoanalytic reading of Hitchcock's The Birds (1963), a gender-subversive and queer hero (Stretch) in The Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2 (1986), and a literal skin job in The Silence of the Lambs (1991), where Buffalo Bill's "fragmented and fragile masculinity" and Dr. Lecter's evil psychology are two sides of the same monstrous coin.
Films Discussed:
The Birds (1963)
Candyman (1992)
Edwards Scissorhands (1990)
Natural Born Killers (1994)

Peeping Tom (1960)

The Silence of the Lambs (1991)
The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (1974)

Title: Ghouls, Gimmicks, and Gold: Horror Films and the American Movie Business, 1953–1968
Author: Heffernan, Kevin
MLA 8 Citation: Heffernan, Kevin. Ghouls, Gimmicks, and Gold: Horror Films and the American Movie Business, 1953–1968. Duke UP, 2004.
Horror Lex Summary:
Heffernan has brought us an entire volume devoted to -- for lack of a better term -- Baby Boomer Horror. As Heffernan relates, legal, technological, and sociological changes in the postwar years, not the least of which was the boom in home television ownership and color film, forever changed the production and reception of horror films. Ghouls, Gimmicks, and Gold celebrates the vibrancy and achievement in films of this period, including their increasing psychological complexity, stylization, and exhibitionism, and the cultural changes in the society watching them.

Each chapter addresses a different facet of horror in the post-war period, including the technological race of the early 1950s and advent of 3-D (Chapter 1); the rise of Hammer Studios and American International Pictures (Chapters 2, 5); and Peeping Tom (1960) and other perceived "art house" and European fare (Chapters 5, 6). Most intriguing are the chapters in which Heffernan gets into less well-known niches. In Chapter 3, he describes the advent of sensationalistic marketing practices such as attention-grabbing slogans, vivd poster art, and even in-theater stagings which helped sell films like The Hypnotic Eye (1960) to a younger, more downscale generation and fill screens after the downturn in major studio productions. 

Heffernan ends the book with the 1968 rise of "adult horror" in Rosemary's Baby and Night of the Living Dead. The former played on old "female Gothic" themes of earlier pictures but ramped up the complexity, profanity, and explicit topics such as abortion. The latter, of course, brought a new bleakness and intense violence, and heightened understanding of the African-American theater market and social segregation. 

As appendices, he includes a list of feature film packages for TV syndication, the subject of Chapter 7.

Title: Pretend We're Dead: Capitalist Monsters in American Pop Culture
Author: Newitz, Annalee
MLA 8 Citation: Newitz, Annalee. Pretend We're Dead: Capitalist Monsters in American Pop Culture. Duke UP, 2006.
Horror Lex Summary:
In this unique book, author Newitz finds a connection between cinematic monsters and what people do for money, even if that connection only "lurks in the background, shaping events and infecting plot lines." 

Newitz poses three categories. First are serial killers and mad doctors (the category of "mental monstrosity") who see murder as their creation, their jobs. They've gone insane because "they lead lives which they perceive as forced on them by profit-driven institutions" -- see Jerry in The Stepfather, whose American Dream demands the perfect family, even if he has to kill to get it -- or in a desperate attempt to keep the economic status that their brains afford them, even if their bodies revolt (as in Re-Animator). Second, she takes up the undead ("bodily monstrosity"), beings that are "disfigured by the very economic practices which grant them immortality and superhuman powers." Here, she notes how monsters such as zombies and robots reflect the "othering" that justified slavery and oppression of racial minorities, something that has been quite openly depicted in certain horror films (e.g., Nightbreed). Finally, there is the "narrative monstrosity" of films like Videodrome and The Ring in which the monster lives in our consumption of mass media and other arms of the capitalist machine. 

Newitz's book is chock-full of references to real-world events and various economic theories, from capitalism to Marxism, as well as literary works, including an extended segment on Lovecraft.

Title: Goth: Undead Subculture
Author: Goodlad, Lauren M. E. and Michael Bibby (Eds.)
Horror Lex Summary:
Ironic for something that draws its name from a medieval era, "goth" is a decidedly 20th-century phenomenon with an instantly recognizable style and a devoted, close-knit following. In Goth: Undead Subculture, editors Goodlad and Bibby attempt a comprehensive, academic discussion of the goth subculture, covering the psychology and motivations of its adherents, as well as their society and norms, fashion, music, and art. 

Contributors have penned essays examining goth subculture from a variety of disciplines, mostly focused on the practical experience of being goth. This includes Kristen Schilt's essay ("Queens of the Damned") in which she describes the behavior and aesthetics of men and women at different U.S. goth clubs, and Jeffrey Andrew Weinstock's tour through "Gothic Fetishism." Others focus on artists and artistic styles that have inspired goths, and in turn, been inspired by them, such as Michael Bibby's chapter ("Atrocity Exhibitions") on the brief career of Joy Division, a goth godfather band. Many contributors also share their personal experiences as a goth.

Film is a minor focus of this collection. In the editors' introduction, they note the appearance of goth style and goth heroes in mainstream Hollywood films such as Beetlejuice, from the de facto goth Pied Piper, Tim Burton, and The Matrix, "in which goth style is deployed to represent authentic opposition" to the status quo. Burton comes up again in  Robert Markley's chapter on Edward Scissorhands ("Geek/Goth"). Vampire cinema is compared against Stoker's classic novel in Nancy Gagnier's essay "The Authentic Dracula." In addition, while not about the film, Lauren Stasiak provides a chapter about horror-lite favorite TV series Buffy the Vampire Slayer ("When You Kiss Me, I Want to Die").

Title: Sleaze Artists: Cinema at the Margins of Taste, Style, and Politics
Author: Sconce, Jeffrey (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Sconce, Jeffrey, editor. Sleaze Artists: Cinema at the Margins of Taste, Style, and Politics. Duke UP, 2007.
Horror Lex Summary:
Whether you call them camp, cult, B-movies, exploitation, schlock, or just plain "bad," films that transgress good taste have never had good reputations, but neither have they lacked audiences  who love them. Editor Sconce has brought together a series of writers to wax philosophic on the art of sleaze, from soft-core porn to monster movies, and ponder what such ill-mannered cinema contributes to the art. 

Essays relevant to the horror genre are: Colin Gunckel's revelation of the little-known Mexican mummy subgenre, in which the country's Aztec past is mined for horror; Kevin Heffernan's history of Mario Bava's Lisa and the Devil (1972), an example of a film deemed "bad art" that was redeemed with the benefit of time and greater appreciation of the lowbrow sensibility; a close listen to the musical scoring of Italian "video nasties," by Kay Dickinson; and Matt Hills' game attempt to defend the Friday the 13th series against the opinion that it is "mainstream trash" rather than "art trash."

Title: The Apartment Complex: Urban Living and Global Screen Cultures
Author: Wojcik, Pamela Robertson (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Wojcik, Pamela Robertson, editor. The Apartment Complex: Urban Living and Global Screen Cultures. Duke UP, 2018.
Horror Lex Summary:
Author Wojcik examines a small domestic world -- the apartment -- and boldly asserts that "the apartment plot in film is a genre." While that remains debatable (subgenre, surely?), there can be no denying that the unique space and temporality of a flat does significant work in oodles of films. 

As Wojcik describes, apartments are urban, temporary, and thin-walled; they can serve as voyeuristic playgrounds or claustrophobic traps. On the subject of apartments in horror films, see Veronica Fitzpatrick's chapter on Roman Polanski's Repulsion, a "domestic horror" film in which the apartment of central character Carol "works to formally surface an as-yet-submerged encounter with past sexual trauma."

Title: Films on Ice: Cinemas of the Arctic
Author: MacKenzie, Scott and Anna Westerstahl Stenport (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: MacKenzie, Scott, and Anna Westerstahl Stenport, editors. Films on Ice: Cinemas of the Arctic. Edinburgh UP, 2014.
Horror Lex Summary:
A sprawling collection of essays that cover every inch of the frozen North on film, from Arctic expedition documentaries and indigenous works to ice-bound slashers to James Bond blockbusters using Icelandic backdrops.

Horror comes up briefly in several chapters: Chapter 7, centering on Finnish-Laplander filmmaker Tommy Wirkola and his horror-parody spins on American films, including 2009's Dead Snow, a "Nazi-zombie-horror-splatter-comedy"; Chapter 11, which notes the thematic similarities between Arctic landscapes and Cold War tensions and discusses films in which these concepts collide, including the original version of The Thing; and Chapter 12, which touches on Iceland as a "beautiful, sublime, and fantastical" shooting location for major Hollywood films, including Prometheus (2012), in which the country stands in for prehistoric Earth. 

In terms of horror, Chapter 13 is the main event. Author Henlin-Strømme explains the concept of "white nature," her name for Norwegian machismo, a tradition stemming from "snow, ice and white men conquering remote regions in harsh conditions." In recent Norwegian horror films, white nature is not triumphant but horrific, in the form of a serial killer (Cold Prey) or the living dead (Dead Snow).

Title: Selling the Splat Pack: The DVD Revolution and The American Horror Film
Author: Bernard, Mark
MLA 8 Citation: Bernard, Mark. Selling the Splat Pack: The DVD Revolution and The American Horror Film. Edinburgh UP, 2014.
Horror Lex Summary:
Bernard gives a glimpse into a peculiarly post-millennium phenomenon: the rise of ultra-violent horror films helmed by a small cadre of directors that attracted the press nickname the Splat Pack: Eli Roth, Alexandre Aje, Rob Zombie, and others. But do not mistake this for a hagiography. Bernard offers more than a healthy dose of skepticism about this group. His main thesis is that while marketed as outsiders who produced "art" of a novel and brave kind, the Splat Pack were solidly located within the Hollywood distribution and promotion machine, the same one that facilitated a similar rise of arty horror in the 1920s/1930s and 1970s.

Bernard's book is less about the movies themselves (although the last few chapters do get into textual analyses) and more about the business. In the first several chapters, he reviews the history of indie-major partnerships, the ratings system, and home video viewership. He ends up post-2000, when "special edition"  and unrated DVDs "transformed once marginal horror movies into mainstream 'art' for collectors." Bernard warns that we're all being played and that certain production companies, especially Lionsgate, have deliberately orchestrated their home video product to allow the industry more control over the film marketplace. 

After that, things get personal. Bernard performs a truly brutal take-down of Eli Roth's self-promoting "hucksterism," accusing the director of manufacturing a political agenda to sell Hostel Part 2 and faking subversion while practicing regression. He is kinder to Rob Zombie, whose films can be seen as progressive in that they "champion the whitetrash underclass and offer no redemption of the middle class," although Bernard notes the latter is exactly to whom Zombie promotes his DVDs. Bernard contrasts these two grandstanders with the makers of the Saw series, who offer no "authorial voice" but rather offer an elaborate puzzle game mythos and "digital theme park" to sell videos.

Author: Partridge, Christopher and Eric Christianson (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Partridge, Christopher, and Eric Christianson, editors. The Lure of the Dark Side: Satan and Western Demonology in Popular Culture. 2009. Routledge, 2014.

Title: Danse Macabre
Author: King, Stephen
MLA 8 Citation: King, Stephen. Danse Macabre. 1981. Gallery Books, 2010.
Horror Lex Summary:
Danse Macabre remains one of the most influential non-fiction books on the horror genre since its publication in 1981. The author, horror-fiction powerhouse Stephen King, is unquestionably the biggest reason why. Although the book was updated with a new King essay in the 2010 version ("What's Scary?") the core book is showing its age -- the obscure Boomer nostalgia references often land with a thud, and the lengthy piece on radio horror seems practically alien at this point. But any horror lover would do well to be familiar with it.

Danse Macabre has indeed contributed to the study of horror, in film, literature, and television. King's distinctions between terror, horror, and revulsion, as well as "Dionysion" horror vs. "Apollonian," are widely quoted. He also touches on some of the more academic aspects of the study of horror, including the "paradox of horror" (i.e., why do people enjoy terrifying things) and psychoanalytic concepts of reintegration and catharsis. On the more populist side, his steadfast defense of bad horror movies -- a not yet "cool" opinion in the pre-irony age of 1981 -- is a nice gift for fans.

The book, alas, lets King run too wild. This is early '80s Stephen King: a rising star with Hollywood deals, a legendary ego, and evidently no one to rein in his nonlinear thinking. The meandering and detour-laden style (from Frankenstein to James Dean to obese people...where were we again?) is often frustrating. And while he does claim that someone asked him for this book -- his editor! -- no one was asking for his frequent denigration of other artists' works (Wes Craven, for one) or his often head-scratching personal tastes to be elevated to fact, such as his gushing ode to the 2009 Last on the House Left remake as one of the best modern horror films, while dismissing Cruising (1980) as  "cheesy." 

King is much more in control when discussing horror novels, but here, too, he gets lost in his own personal fascinations. One could almost have read Peter Straub's Ghost Story or Anne Rivers Siddons's The House Next Door in the time that King takes to detail their characters and plots, and if you haven't read them, King is pleased to leave you in his dust.

Ultimately, Danse Macabre is at its best when it speaks to what its author does best: write horror novels. King does not frequently promote his own works here, but the few tidbits he provides on the writing of Carrie and the inspiration for The Stand are like diamonds. More important, in discussing what makes the creators and audiences of horror fiction tick, he ultimately tells us what makes him tick. For even casual fans of King, that knowledge is worthwhile.

Title: Fear Without Frontiers: Horror Cinema Across the Globe
Author: Schneider, Steven Jay (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Schneider, Steven Jay, editor. Fear Without Frontiers: Horror Cinema Across the Globe. FAB Press, 2003.
Horror Lex Summary:
As established in the Preface by veteran horror film critic Kim Newman, horror cinema may have begun with American films based on British literature, but horror film culture in a larger sense has its roots in folktales and lore from around the globe. In more recent decades, horror has seen an explosive increase in international production. Fear Without Frontiers aims to introduce those already grounded in the basics of the Anglo-American horror tradition to new cultures, stories, and talent.

The book is well-stacked (over 300 pages) with a good variety of chapters. Readers who have already dipped a toe into European horror cinema will likely enjoy the chapters on giallos and Paul Naschy. J-horror gets its own section, with chapters on director Takashi Miike and some of the better-known film series, like Ringu. But the real value of this book lies in the chapters on more obscure corners of the horror globe. André Barcinski writes about director José Mojica Marins, featuring his Coffin Joe character, which brought an unprecedented level of violence and Catholic heresy to midcentury Brazil. Gary D. Rhodes provides a characteristically well-written chapter on foundational Mexican horror cinema of the 1930s, well before the better-known El Santo and Mexican wrestling came to the screen. Pete Tombs also gives a solid overview of India's Bollywood horror, including foundational films and the decades of output from the Ramsay Brothers.

Title: Book of the Dead: The Complete History of Zombie Cinema
Author: Russell, Jamie
MLA 8 Citation: Russell, Jaime. Book of the Dead: The Complete History of Zombie Cinema. 2005. Revised ed., Titan, 2014.
Horror Lex Summary:
A stout and smart volume all about the undead. Author Russell defends the often marginalized zombie subgenre -- "the great unwashed of horror cinema" -- that can boast no highbrow literary history. He writes a comprehensive Bible of zombies on film, covering the Caribbean origins; '50s paranoia; Romero's seminal Night of the Living Dead and the rest of his ouevre; the Italian splatter flicks and Spanish "Blind Dead" series; Sam Raimi's Evil Dead; Resident Evil and other undead-based video games; and finally, the post-9/11 explosion of zombie fears, beaming into every household via The Walking Dead. 

Russell's research digs deep, including from primary sources, and he analyzes all the major films front, back, and sideways. Particularly sharp is Russell's convincing ability to bring movies into the zombie subgenre that do not fit the traditional mold, such as Shivers. At the back of the book, there is an exclusive interview with George Romero in which he looks back at the genre that he made nearly single-handedly. You'll also find an exhaustive encyclopedia of zombie movies with just enough description to decide if the film is for you. 

Hard to imagine a more complete rundown of the topic, and the 2014 revision substantially added to the text.

Title: Making Friday the 13th: The Legend of Camp Blood
Author: Grove, David
MLA 8 Citation: Grove, David. Making Friday the 13th: The Legend of Camp Blood. FAB Press, 2005.
Horror Lex Summary:
A sprawling, series-spanning story of the making of the Friday the 13th films, from the original in 1980 to Freddy vs. Jason in 2003. (The only thing the book misses is the 2009 remake -- which shows you how long it's been since we've had a proper Friday.) Grove's book beat Peter Bracke's similar Crystal Lake Memories (see separate listing on Horror Lex) by just a year, and to that point, Grove had gotten unprecedented access to the creative teams and business personnel responsible for one of the biggest franchises of the 1980s. The sheer amount of interview work represented here is staggering.

The result is, in one sense, a typical "making of" book -- each film gets one or two chapters with information on the story development and preproduction, casting, filming, and box office scores. There is too much padding in terms of recounting plot details and dense listings of prior and subsequent credits for the actors. But Grove's interviews provide detail that you simply can't get from IMDB, such as Tom Savini relishing the creation of Jason's would-be death in Part IV, and Kane Hodder talking about his disappointment in not reprising the Jason role after Jason X. Every alternative ending and continuity snafu is covered. The book also tries to be coffee-table-worthy in terms of publishing quality - and while it doesn't quite get there, it is fully decked out with (small) film stills, behind-the-scenes photos, and marketing materials, with a section in the middle in full color.

For Friday the 13th fans, this is a no-brainer buy.
Films Discussed:
A Bay of Blood (a.k.a. Twitch of the Death Nerve) (1971)
Freddy vs. Jason (2003)
Friday the 13th (1980)

Title: Nightmare USA: The Untold Story of the Exploitation Independents
Author: Thrower, Stephen
MLA 8 Citation: Thrower, Stephen. Nightmare USA: The Untold Story of the Exploitation Independents. FAB Press, 2007.
Horror Lex Summary:
Undertaking the Herculean task of tracking down every (or at least most) non-studio horror film from 1970-1985, Stephen Thrower has produced one hell of a book. It's huge, it's heavy, it's stocked with interviews, reviews, photos, and posters. It's perhaps a bit... much. But for those obsessed with the obscure, especially of the 1970s-1980s variety, this is both a key sourcebook and hours of entertainment.

Thrower starts with an essay that attempts to capture what it means to be an "independent" horror or exploitation film and sketch a history of the decades' most notable entries. The sheer weirdness of these films, he concludes, is "a combination of accident and artistic ambition," given that most were made by nonprofessionals on borrowed money, a cheap camera, and just enough friends willing to put on a rubber mask or stage blood. He notes that indie films of the period bear enviable "cultural plurality" given the favorable economic conditions and because the geography of U.S. made it possible to create very different movies in different corners of nation. Thrower also highlights certain subgenres that took hold with audiences, such as slashers, near-pornos, and all variety of monster flicks, and gives solid recommendations for the best in each category.

Thrower then launches into a series of chapters, each highlighting a notable film or filmmaker, and almost all including original interviews. Gems here include Chapter 4, on the New Jersey production of The Deadly Spawn (1983), featuring a legendary monster puppet, "a triumph of low-budget dedication and design"; Chapter 20, featuring the films of Norman Thaddeus Vane (The Black Room, Frightmare a.k.a. The Horror Star, and Midnight), all of which you're going to want to see immediately; and Chapter 23, which chronicles the production of arguably the most WTF indie horror of all time, Death Bed: The Bed That Eats (1977). 

Throwing light on individual films in-depth is a great way of going about this kind of book; it would be so easy to get lost in an encyclopedia-style death march through every film. If comprehensiveness is what you crave, however, he wraps up with a handy review section containing over 100 films.

Title: House of Psychotic Women: An Autobiographical Topography of Female Neurosis in Horror and Exploitation Films
Author: Janisse, Kier-La
MLA 8 Citation: Janisse, Kier-La. House of Psychotic Women: An Autobiographical Topography of Female Neurosis in Horror and Exploitation Films. FAB Press, 2012.
Horror Lex Summary: A truly unique entry into the world of horror writing, Janisse's House is part memoir, part academic treatise. The author is frank and vivid in describing her trauma-filled early life, to the point of inducing a nearly unbearable squirmy feeling of voyeurism in the reader (such as when she decsribes witnessing her mother's rape). But then, isn't that what horror films do? Janisse deftly weaves her personal stories of pain with analyses of horror and exploitation films, primarily those that are driven by female neuroses, either real or societally dictated -- from early '70s gialli to rape-revenge to Martyrs. You may not be able to see yourself in her stories, but you will enjoy the window into someone else's world.

Title: Satanic Panic: Pop-Cultural Paranoia in the 1980s
Author: Janisse, Kier-La and Paul Corupe (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Janisse, Kier-La, and Paul Corupe, editors. Satanic Panic: Pop-Cultural Paranoia in the 1980s. FAB Press/Spectacular Optical, 2016.
Horror Lex Summary:
Anyone who lived through the 1980s in the Western world likely had a favorite song, movie, or game that was -- for reasons only your parents or teachers could apparently understand -- accused of being in league with Satan. This book resurrects that era in an attempt to explain it, and hopefully bury it forever. 

In 20 snappy chapters, authors from around the world of academia and pop culture each examine a small slice of the 1980s Satanic Panic, from Twisted Sister to pulp novels to Dungeons and Dragons. Films are the focus of several chapters, including Samm Deighan's fun history of heavy metal-themed horror films that will likely have you adding to your Netflix queue, and Kurt Halfyard's paean to The 'Burbs, which, at the end of the decade, was finally able to have some laughs about America's devil obsession. There are additional standouts, including Nastasi's chapter about Satan-worship themes in erotic fiction and Heller-Nicholas's chapter about a famous case of "repressed memories" chronicled in the non-fiction book Michelle Remembers. 

A delight for anyone with a personal history from the Satanic Panic era, and a fascinating time capsule for anyone who doesn't.

Title: Games of Terror: Halloween, Friday the 13th, and the Films of the Stalker Cycle
Author: Dika, Vera
MLA 8 Citation: Dika, Vera. Games of Terror: Halloween, Friday the 13th, and the Films of the Stalker Cycle. Fairleigh Dickinson UP, 1990.
Horror Lex Summary:
Dika's tome on the slasher trend from 1978-1981 is one of just two well-known academic treatments of the subject (the other being Carol J. Clover's Men, Women and Chainsaws; see separate entry on Horror Lex). In her introduction, Dika explains the conundrum that slashers provide: while the films are almost universally panned, teenagers eat them up, as evidenced by the huge box office success of even minor entrants into the subgenre.

Dika suggests that it is intellectually lazy, as well as inaccurate, to chalk up the success of slashers to their violence and gore. One of her most useful insights is that slashers excel at gaming: by use of point-of-view shots and other visual/auditory revelations to the audience about where the killer is and when and how he might strike, audiences are directly engaged in a game, and they show their engagement, often by yelling right back at the screen ("don't go in there!!"). The schlockier the effects (the "anti-illusion"), the more audiences will interpret violence as a game, not reality.

Perhaps the most rewarding aspect of the book is that Dika has clearly watched and paid attention to these much-maligned films, which many critics do not. She gets the plot details right -- in fact, she creates an entire deep structure for the films, which gets repeated in each iteration, all stemming from Psycho and Halloween -- and avoids making generalizations that she can't back up. Better yet, she smartly deflates generalizations from other writers that are still sometimes heard today (e.g., teen victims are always sexually promiscuous) and brings true innovation to the analysis of slashers, including regarding the function of the POV camera and nature of the Final Girl.

Published in 1990, Games of Terror is admittedly outdated; literally hundreds of slashers have been released since then, and it's missing the new slasher boom kicked off by Scream in 1996, plus the spate of remakes in the 2000s. Yet perhaps this works to the book's benefit, because it remains a time capsule of how slashers were perceived during and just after their initial boom. 

A must-read for any horror scholar or fan of the subgenre -- good luck finding a copy though, check your local library.

Title: Hearths of Darkness: The Family in the American Horror Film
Author: Williams, Tony
MLA 8 Citation: Williams, Tony. Hearths of Darkness: The Family in the American Horror Film. 1996. Updated ed., UP of Mississippi, 2014.
Horror Lex Summary:
(Note: Book summary is based on the first edition.)

From author Williams' perspective, the American nuclear family is a harmful and "dysfunctional institution" that would be better off eliminated -- but you don't have to buy into that philosophy to enjoy this examination of horror emanting from the family's bosom. Families, Williams argues, are a veritable garden of the paranoia, threats, and violence that modern horror runs upon, and postmodern horror seems to agree. 

Hearths of Darkness is populated largely with detailed walk-throughs of key films with commentary from the author, organized roughly by film type. Williams starts with the classics, discussing (among others) Frankenstein and its sequels in terms of Mary Shelley's novel, which reflects her rage at rigid family and gender formations that affected her personally. Speaking of Psycho and the rest of Hitchcock's oeuvre, Williams offers that they depict men and women struggling against the Oedipal trajectory that patriarchy demands, often causing regression into psychosis. Next, Williams addresses the unholy trilogy of films in which families are infiltrated by Satanic impulses: Rosemary's Baby, The Exorcist (and Exorcist II, which the author breathlessly endorses), and The Omen. 

Moving forward, Williams catalogs how family institutions became associated with the carnage of Vietnam, from the explicit (Deathdream) to the veiled (Last House on the Left, The Crazies), and associated with the apocalypse in Texas Chain Saw Massacre. He wraps up with a brief (and disapproving) survey of '80s slashers, whose monstrous fathers (Freddy, Jason, Michael) reflected the resurgence of patriarchal norms, and finally, sums up the golden '80s period of Stephen King adaptations.

Title: Splatter Movies: Breaking the Last Taboo of the Screen
Author: McCarty, John
MLA 8 Citation: McCarty, John. Splatter Movies: Breaking the Last Taboo of the Screen. 1981. St Martin's Press, 1984.
Horror Lex Summary:
"Splatter movies," author McCarty explains, "aim not to scare their audiences…but to mortify them with scenes of explicit gore." While one could quibble with his thesis that gory horror movies form their own subgenre, there is no denying that, starting in earnest in the 1960s, gore exploded both as an art form and as a cinematic goal. Writing in 1981, McCarty was the vanguard on this topic. In fact, the datedness of the book is a handicap, given how much "splatter" came after its publication. At the same time, it remains a fascinating glimpse of the scene at the time it was still fresh and controversial.

McCarty begins with a brief history of gory entertainment and censorship thereof, from the Grand Guignol theater to early filmmakers such as D.W. Griffiths. At that point, his book becomes a chronological guide, starting with Hammer films; moving to Herschell Gordon Lewis, Night of the Living Dead, and Cronenberg; and then the "mainstream" tentpole films of the 1970s and early '80s. 

Don't miss the Easter egg interviews: starting on page 101, McCarty talks to a hot-property David Cronenberg, fresh off Scanners, and at page 124, there's a chat with Tom Savini just before the debut of Creepshow. This is a handsome book, albeit with only black-and-white photos. Picking up a gently-used copy may be worth your time.

Title: American Nightmare: Essays on the Horror Film
Author: Wood, Robin and Richard Lippe (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Wood, Robin and Richard Lippe, editors. American Nightmare: Essays on the Horror Film. Festival of Festivals, 1979.
Horror Lex Summary:
American Nightmare is a publication more often referred to than actually read. Part of that is due to its unusual origin -- as a 100-page pamphlet distributed to attendees of the 1979 Festival of Festivals (now known as the Toronto Film Festival), at which Robin Wood and some of his like-minded critics presented on the horror film. At the time, placing horror films among "serious" films and writing about them with academic pretentions was unheard of. Thus, the 100-page pamphlet (which is available free on the web, see link) has gone down in history as the beginning of the acceptance of horror films as a genre worthy of study. 

That being said, there is not much diversity in this first attempt. Wood, Lippe, and fellow authors Andrew Britton and Tony Williams were all cut from similar cloth -- left-wing/Marxist in political stance, and firm believers in Freudian psychoanalytic theory, which would dominate horror criticism for the next decade or longer. And while Wood (and perhaps others) explicitly identified as a feminist, there's not a woman to be found here. Still, this is essential reading for anyone interested in 1970s critical film history or looking for a firm grounding in the principles that guide today's horror critics.

One particular chapter that has gone on to become cannon is Wood's Introduction to the American Horror Film. In this essay, Wood fleshes out his Freud-based theory of the underpinning of all horror films, which is that the return of a societally repressed desire is the monster, which threatens normality.

Title: Queer as Camp: Essays on Summer, Style, and Sexuality
Author: Kidd, Kenneth B. and Derritt Mason (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Kidd, Kenneth B., and Derritt Mason, editors. Queer as Camp: Essays on Summer, Style, and Sexuality. Fordham UP, 2019.
Horror Lex Summary:
Ahhhh, summer camp. Softball. Canoeing. Macramé. And often, a hotbed of gender anxiety and first loves. Sixteen contributors offer their takes on the intersection between queer sexuality and the phenomenon of attending camp. The authors' perspectives are broad-ranging, covering experiences of girls, boys, Americans, Jews, Australians, even kids in Japanese internment camps. Linking most of their stories is Susan Sontag's famous "Notes on Camp," a 1964 essay (not included here, but free online) which was arguably the first attempt to define the camp sensibility from an academic standpoint. As the essays demonstrate, the "camp" experience and the "camp" aesthetic share more than a coincidental name.

Chris McGee's chapter on Sleepaway Camp (1983), "one of the most bizarre and infamous entries" in the slasher movie canon, explains how the film "tells both a literal queer story" in the gender-bending character of Angela "and an odder, deeper, queerer, more complex story in its subtext." McGee explores the film's surface-level depiction of queerness as monstrous, but posits that Angela, in truth, is the film's most sympathetic figure: the one who suffers most from the demands of heteronormativity and bullying in a classic American summer camp setting, with their swimsuits and communal showers.
Films Discussed:

Title: Handbook of American Film Genres
Author: Gehring, Wes D. (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Gehring, Wes D., editor. Handbook of American Film Genres. Greenwood, 1988.
Horror Lex Summary:
A textbook-style introduction to horror as a cinematic genre, covering the early 20th century through the end of the 1970s. Author Gehring name-checks seminal films and offers a brief comment on their significance. 

Most interesting is Gehring's take on the 1970s. While he nods in the direction of the auteurs Kubrick, Friedkin, and Spielberg, he asserts that “the best work has actually been done by supposedly second-rate directors," Cronenberg, Hooper, Craven, and Ferrera. He has particular love for Ferrera's Ms. 45, which offers a “refreshing inversion” of violent film plots. The author also provides a useful (if now very outdated) review of relevant books and journals.

Title: Film, Horror, and the Body Fantastic
Author: Badley, Linda
MLA 8 Citation: Badley, Linda. Film, Horror, and the Body Fantastic. Greenwood, 1995.
Horror Lex Summary:
One of the earliest studies into the horror genre amidst the cultural context of the human body, inspired by the rise of gothic pop culture in the 1980s. 

Author Badley describes 1980s horror culture, with its gore and nauseating effects, as "a spectacle offering not mere transcendence of the body but transcendence through the body." This gothic body, as she demonstrates, manifested in film. Think of the hauntings from spectral, womb-like spaces (such as in Poltergeist and The Shining) spawned by characters' empty souls. Or, the vulnerable, revolting bodies (and bodies in revolt) in zombie films and gore-heavy flicks like Re-Animator. 

Badley also questions the theory that slasher flicks are always bad for women, and devotes two chapters to movies directed by men that "began to invert and challenge the patriarchal codes of the genre." This includes Body Double ("an elaborate, self-referential joke" about misogyny) and the entire early Cronenberg ouevre. Her final chapter examines The Silence of the Lambs (a "women's picture"), the theme of the mother, and the cross-gender play that both Clarice Starling and Jame Gumb engage in "out of a similar need, emptiness, and loss."

Title: Violence in Popular Culture: American and Global Perspectives
Author: Finley, Laura L. (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Finley, Laura L., editor. Violence in Popular Culture: American and Global Perspectives. Greenwood, 2018.
Horror Lex Summary:
An encyclopedia-type book with listings relating to different forms of media violence, arranged by type of media -- radio, film, TV, music, literature, and video games. Editor Finley writes mini-essays at the beginning of the volume and each section, surveying the history of violent imagery and ideas, and explaining how they've come into contact with our eyes and ears. Finley does not take a principled position that violent media makes violent people (although one wonders why she would bother to write this book otherwise), but instead keeps a rather dry distance.  

In the Film section, horror films are discussed with respect to individual seminal films, and series and trends (e.g., blaxploitation, slasher films). However, the text rarely goes beyond a description of the plot and violent content in each film.

Title: The Pyrotechnic Insanitarium: American Culture on the Brink
Author: Dery, Mark
MLA 8 Citation: Dery, Mark. The Pyrotechnic Insanitarium: American Culture on the Brink. Grove, 2000.
Horror Lex Summary:
The Psychotechnic Insanitarium is Dery's collection of essays on popular culture, focused on certain "megatrends and microshifts of American culture late in the twentieth century" that reflect a common, and rather messed-up, consciousness. Dery warns readers upfront that if one is looking for "point-by-point exposition and the methodical accumulation of evidence," best look elsewhere. Instead, expect highly esoteric yet readable musings on politics, mass media, and hidden corners of millennial life, loosely bound into a psychoanalytic/philosophical framework.

While none of Dery's essays centers directly on horror films, Wes Craven's Scream series figures prominently in the first chapter, in which Dery identifies Edward Munch's 19th-century painting The Scream (reflected in the cinematic killer's costume) as "the poster child for self-mocking millennial dread." In Chapter 2, the author finds creepy clowns, from Pennywise to the Killer Klowns from Outer Space to John Wayne Gacy, to fill the role of "agents of chaos" whose symbolic sacrifice is a "means of appeasing the turbulent forces that seem to be pulling our world off its axis" as it hurtles toward the millennium. Finally, in Chapter 12, Kenneth Branaugh's cinematic version of Frankenstein gets a brief mention in Dery's essay on new concepts of birth.
Films Discussed:
Chapter 1: Have an Angst Day: The Scream Meme
・Scream (1996)

Chapter 2: Cotton Candy Autopsy: Deconstructing Pscyho-Killer Clowns
・Killer Clowns from Outer Space (1988)
・Poltergeist (1982)
・The Shining (1980)

Chapter 12: Empathy Bellies: Cloned Sheep and Pregnant Men
・Mary Shelley's Frankenstein (1994)
Tags: millennium, sociology, clowns, serial killers, Frankenstein, Mary Shelley, birth, pregnancy

Title: Slash of the Titans: The Road to Freddy vs Jason
Author: McNeill, Dustin
MLA 8 Citation: McNeill, Dustin. Slash of the Titans: The Road to Freddy vs Jason. Harker, 2017.
Horror Lex Summary:
Freddy vs Jason (2003) was the grudge match every fanboy and fangirl had been waiting for. In one corner, Freddy Krueger, the dream king of the lucrative Nightmare on Elm Street series. In the other, Jason Voorhees, prolific slasher from the Friday the 13th movies. It may have seemed like a natural pairing, à là Frankenstein meeting the Wolf Man. But insiders know that it was a long, long, looooong road to this match-up, and McNeill is here to dish on every last detail.

In Slash of the Titans, McNeill describes the initial conception of a Freddy vs Jason film, way back in the mid-1980s, and then steers readers into a chronological trip through 10 major draft screenplays and treatments of the film that would take the rest of the decade to suss out. (In fact, as McNeill notes, it would take a formal arbitration by the Writers Guild to determine the  screenwriting credits for the finished film.) The drafts ranged from the dull (copycat killers, ho hum) to the offbeat (a "Fredhead" fan cult, and Jason goes on trial!) to the truly WTF (Freddy had sex with Jason's mom??). McNeill neatly summarizes them all, and adds his original interviews with nearly all the major players, including the screenwriters, New Line and Cunningham Productions execs, and Robert Englund.

This may be obvious, but Slash of the Titans is for diehard Nightmare and/or Friday fans only. (And only the diehard could be expected to wade through this typo-ridden edition; not sure this got any editing at all.) Thankfully, McNeill addresses many burning questions that fans have had about Freddy vs Jason. Why wasn't Kane Hodder playing Jason? Where did the versions with Pinhead and Ash from The Evil Dead go? And why on Earth does Jason appear to be afraid of water, given that he spent Friday XIII voluntarily swimming from New Jersey to New York City? 

If you read only one book about Freddy vs Jason -- and let's face it, the world only needs one -- let this be it.
Films Discussed:
Freddy vs. Jason (2003)
Friday the 13th (series)
Friday the 13th Part VII: The New Blood (1988)
Friday the 13th Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan (1989)
Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday (1993)
Wes Craven's New Nightmare (1994)

Title: Taking Shape: Developing Halloween from Script to Scream
Author: McNeill, Dustin and Travis Mullins
MLA 8 Citation: McNeill, Dustin and Travis Mullins. Taking Shape: Developing Halloween from Script to Scream. Harker, 2019.
Horror Lex Summary:
In the last few years, horror lovers have been gifted with comprehensive retrospectives on several horror franchises, but the Halloween series has been neglected until now. Authors McNeill and Mullins aim to provide an A-to-Z history of the original 1978 John Carpenter film and its many sequels and reboots (and sequels to the reboots, and reboots of the sequels) over the last 40 years. 

Taking Shape is structured chronologically by film, with the discussion almost entirely focused on the film's various texts: original and alternative versions of the script, the narrative and plot of the movie as filmed, deleted scenes, edited-for-television versions, directors' and producers' cuts, and post-film novelizations. Some readers, especially more casual Halloween fans, may find this tack overly repetitive or just plain dull. (If you don't care whether the first version of the Halloween 5 script had The Man in Black wearing a suit rather than a cowboy duster, this won't change things.) But slasher fans, by their nature, tend to love repetition and will probably revel in every new nugget of information (e.g., the scene with the retractable gym-floor pool that was cut out of cost concerns from Halloween: H20, which would have been a-ma-zing). And even for those well-versed in Hollywood Halloween lore, there will be plenty of new information here, including 17 new interviews with directors, writers, producers, and others involved in the making of the films.

The narrow focus of Taking Shape does mean that extra-textual consideration of the series is virtually absent. The only film that receives any deeper consideration is the original Halloween (1978), and the authors ultimately adopt the director's own infamous view of the film: in short, it's just about a guy who kills people, and everyone should stop looking for more meaning.

Title: Nightmare on Main Street: Angels, Sadomasochism, and the Culture of Gothic
Author: Edmundson, Mark
MLA 8 Citation: Edmundson, Mark. Nightmare on Main Street: Angels, Sadomasochism, and the Culture of Gothic. Harvard UP, 1997.
Horror Lex Summary:
"[I]n '90s America it seemed that almost everyone was tied up, in one way or another, with the Gothic," author Edmundson observes. Stephen King, R.L. Stine, and Anne Rice books were in every home, The X-Files was on TV, and a Hannibal Lecter movie won Best Picture. 

Putting aside the obvious, the author focuses on The Gothic ("the art of haunting") in more hidden nooks of the decade, spurred by our pre-millennial anxiety and need to find deeper meaning in the darkness due to our sharply decreased reliance on religiosity. This includes the O.J. Simpson case, which Edmundson argues is a "Gothic slasher" and classic Jekyll-and-Hyde tale; afternoon talk shows, which wallow in trauma, recovered memories, and historical retellings; and even the "pop transcendent," anti-Gothic celebrated in Forrest Gump. 

In short, there is no element of 1990s pop culture or tabloid news (Tanya Harding!) that Edmundson cannot wedge into a Gothic box. The author gives shallow treatment to horror fims, but seeing him move from Freddy Kreuger to The Lion King to Camille Paglia to Foucault in the space of a few pages is a stunt some may want to see for themselves.

Title: Are You In The House Alone? A TV Movie Compendium 1964-1999
Author: Reyes, Amanda (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Reyes, Amanda, editor. Are You In The House Alone? A TV Movie Compendium 1964-1999. Headpress, 2017.
Horror Lex Summary:
Amanda Reyes is unquestionably the preeminent historian of made-for-television movies, and this was the book she had to write. Anyone who grew up in the '60s-'90s, before movies could be had with a few clicks of a remote, remembers glueing themselves to the TV set at an appointed time or setting the VCR to catch something violent, scary, salacious, or just plain exciting on TV, such as Dark Night of the Scarecrow (1981) and Mother May I Sleep With Danger? (1996). 

While not limited to horror-themed TV movies, the book notes their special place in this corner of history. The television movie "became a looking glass into the world of genre cinema," Reyes notes, especially for those who lived outside major cities and had no access to grindhouse moviehouses or rare videotapes. 

Are You in the House Alone? is best used as a reference book rather than a cover-to-cover read. The essays, written by Reyes and guests, are brief and do little more than collect and recap films on the same topic. Yet horror fans will especially appreciate Lance Vaughan's overview of Stephen King TV adaptations, including the still-nightmare-inducing Salem's Lot (1979) and It (1990). Also notable is Jennifer Wallis's thoughtful roundup of rape-revenge TV films, in which she considers them against the political backdrop of the times. 

The back half of the book contains a nearly comprehensive set of reviews of made-for-TV movies in each decade, the most engaging of which are written by Reyes herself and guest reviewers Kier-La Janisse and Kevin Hilton. Your nostalgia will surely be triggered, and your Netflix list will surely grow, after perusing. Happy (re-)discoveries!

Title: Legacy of Blood: A Comprehensive Guide To Slasher Movies
Author: Harper, Jim
MLA 8 Citation: Harper, Jim. Legacy of Blood: A Comprehensive Guide To Slasher Movies. Headpress, 2004.
Horror Lex Summary:
Author Harper starts his book with a sparse yet competent march through slasher history, grounded in the opinion that Halloween is the apex of slasherdom and everything else that followed, save A Nightmare on Elm Street or two, was an increasing disappointment. This is perhaps a defensible position, but seems an odd one for someone dedicating an entire book to the slasher subgenre. 

More worthwhile is Harper’s 25-page slasher anatomy lesson, in which he dissects slasher tropes. He enthusiastically joins the debate on Final Girls (and offers fresh insight into the “virginal or nay?” question), the nature of the killer, and the classic setting of isolation. The heart of the book, though, is in Harper’s reviews of 190 slasher pix. While he misses key films (no The Funhouse?) at the same time, he lists many others that are new to this die-hard slasher fan, particular from the early aughts. 

In the end, though, Harper's neutral-to-negative tone throughout the reviews is puzzling, as if the author has an intellectual curiosity about slashers but no true love for their goofy charm. Simply put, if you don't love Bloody Moon and Pieces, we can’t be friends.

Title: From Reverence to Rape: The Treatment of Women in the Movies
Author: Haskell, Molly
MLA 8 Citation: Haskell, Molly. From Reverence to Rape: The Treatment of Women in the Movies. 1974. 3rd ed., U Chicago P, 2016.
Horror Lex Summary:
An influential (albeit aging) text on the subject of women and film, From Reverence to Rape was written in 1974 by a Southern film critic who offered an explicitly second-wave feminist viewpoint. Her goal: to shame misogyny and promote the equality of women in film, not just in the director's chair and other positions of power, but on screen. 

Haskell begins with "The Big Lie," that is, that women are inferior -- intellectually, physically, emotionally -- and thus may be fairly depicted in film as objects of subjection and sacrifice. She then proves her point by mulling through four decades of Hollywood output, in which actresses are steadfastly prevented from depicting their characters as people. Instead, they were virgins, whores, harridans. Women were rarely protagonists rather than "an adjunct to man" - except, of course, in so-called "women's films," the existence of which speaks for itself. Not that Haskell spends the entire book merely listing films and complaining. Her deep affection for cinema and knowledge of the plots, metaphors, and meanings of films from the '20s through the early '70s is self-evident, and, thankfully, she can find small corners of female victory.

Horror fans will find little to chew on here; the seminal horror and sci-fi films of the '30s through the '50s are almost completely untouched. But it's worth the wait: in her chapter regarding the '60s, Haskell unleashes a truly blistering critique on certain auteurs of the day -- Polanski, Hitchcock, Kubrick, and Peckinpah -- whose work and choice of actresses reveal deep, real-life chauvinism.
Films Discussed:
2001: A Space Odyssey (1968)
The Birds (1963)
Blue Velvet (1986)
A Clockwork Orange (1971)
Deliverance (1972)
Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb (1964)
Dressed to Kill (1980)
The Fearless Vampire Killers (1967)
Frenzy (1972)
Ms. 45 (1981)

Title: Sexual Stratagems: The World of Women in Film
Author: Erens, Patricia (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Erens, Patricia. Sexual Stratagems: The World of Women in Film. Horizon, 1979.
Horror Lex Summary:
Erens and her contributors assess the state of male-dominated cinema (circa 1979) and the changes that feminist critics and female filmmakers are ushering into that arena. 

The book is not greatly concerned with the horror genre, except for Gérard Lenne's chapter regarding the figure of women as both victims and monsters in horror films. Lenne notes the different roles that women play in different "fantastic" narratives -- such as the sexually active role for female characters in vampire films -- but resignedly admits that every time, she is relegated to the bottom ranks, or secondary in importance to mere beauty. Even when she is the monster, she is never one of the "great psychopaths, the figureheads of the fantastic." On point, but not terribly heartening.

Title: Children, Cinema and Censorship: From Dracula to the Dead End Kids
Author: Smith, Sarah J.
MLA 8 Citation: Smith, Sarah J. Children, Cinema and Censorship: From Dracula to the Dead End Kids. I.B. Tauris, 2005.
Horror Lex Summary:
A history of 1930s American and British moral panics surrounding the cinema, especially regarding films that -- as popularly believed -- would prove indecent and harmful when viewed by children. 

Author Smith devotes a significant section to the novel "talkie" horrors such as Frankenstein, deemed unsuitable for children and slapped with a new rating of "Horrific." She also provides individuals' reminisces of being children in this era (via exhaustive research into original sources), in which they talk about experiencing both the thrills and the terror of watching these controversial films, often without the knowledge of their parents.
