Title: Horror Zone: The Cultural Experience of Contemporary Horror Cinema
Author: Conrich, Ian (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Conrich, Ian, editor. Horror Zone: The Cultural Experience of Contemporary Horror Cinema. I.B. Tauris, 2009.
Horror Lex Summary:
Most books about horror films rely upon deep, textual readings. Fewer have treated horror not merely as a collection of films, but as a culture. Editor Conrich has put together this volume to fill that gap. The 15 all-star contributors address different aspects of being a modern horror consumer and fan: horror as multifaceted entertainment, spreading to theme parks and blockbuster films; the technological expansion of the horror subculture, including online communities; and the cultural boundaries pushed by horror. 

The span of this book is vast and the topics varied, but a few chapters stood out. Hands down, the favorite is Julian Petley's Chapter 12, which attempts to bring some historical sense to the gruesome "Nazi horrors" subgenre, peaking in the 1970s with the SS and Ilsa films. Also worthwhile are Chapter 8, a brief but entertaining look at the different strategies in set design and costuming in three films based on serial killer Ed Gein, and Chapter 11, which sees parallels in the body aesthetics of splatter films like Pieces and hard-core pornography.

Title: The Child in Film: Tears, Fears and Fairy Tales
Author: Lury, Karen
MLA 8 Citation: Lury, Karen. The Child in Film: Tears, Fears and Fairy Tales. I.B. Tauris, 2010.
Horror Lex Summary:
The Child in Film is a thoughtful set of essays addressing certain themes that often accompany child-centered films. The themes are almost uniformly unhappy ones -- trauma, neglect, sexual abuse, war. As author Lury writes in the introduction, her inspiration was the sense that, as depicted cinematically, the child and childhood "occupy a situation in which they are 'other': other to the supposedly rational, civilised, 'grown up' human animal that is the adult."

Two chapters touch on the horror genre, primarily Chapter 1, where Lury examines Japanese horror films centering on ghostly children, many of which were remade for American audiences. She finds something distinctive about the use of the child in the Japanese versions of the stories. Sadako (Ringu), Mitsuko (Dark Water), and similar bereft, dead kids represent a warped perspective of time. By serving as a constant reminder of a troubled past, they now threaten the coherence of the present, and essentially collapse the two. The location of the troubled past within the figure of a child -- as both victim and threat -- is also meaningful, Lury writes. To Japan, a nation that suffered both post-World War II trauma and a deep recession in the 1990s, the fate of children was heavily invested in as a symbol of national identity. The failure of those children to thrive, or worse, their abandonment or murder, carries meaning beyond the children themselves.

In Chapter 3, Lury surveys films that depict war through the eyes and experiences of children. While most of the films are dramas, not horror, she does point to Guillermo del Toro's Pan's Labyrinth as an example of a film that depicts war through a fairytale lens, with a focus on children interacting with elemental powers (fire, earth).

Title: Studies in Entertainment: Critical Approaches to Mass Culture
Author: Modleski, Tania (Ed.)
MLA 8 Citation: Modleski, Tania, editor. Studies in Entertainment: Critical Approaches to Mass Culture. Indiana UP, 1986.
Horror Lex Summary:
Modleski presents a series of essays on a wide array of mass media formats -- books, sitcoms, films, advertising, even television news -- each commenting on sociological issues laid bare in their texts or subtexts. True to the mid-1980s era of these writings, certain approaches predominate: feminist, psychoanalytic, Marxist, and philosophical. 

Modleski herself contributes a chapter on horror films, where she defends against criticism of slashers and other "low" genre forms merely because they provide  predictable, visceral pleasures. To the contrary, she claims, horror films can be seen as the kind of transgressive, anti-bourgeois force that Marxist/postmodernists have been looking for. Movies such as The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (1974) and The Brood (1979) present "an unprecedented assault on all that bourgeois culture is supposed to cherish," like the patriarchal family. Such films also engender "joyful self-destructiveness" on the part of the audience, who cheer at mad slashers killing teenagers they never really knew, and destroying a social order they don't actually cherish.
Films Discussed:

Title: Contemporary Indonesian Film: Spirits of Reform and Ghosts from the Past
Author: van Heeren, Katinka
MLA 8 Citation: van Heeren, Katinka. Contemporary Indonesian Film: Spirits of Reform and Ghosts from the Past. Brill, 2012.
Horror Lex Summary: In her survey of Indonesian film, author van Heeren devotes Chapter 5 to the horror genre, in both film and television. Indonesian horror, she explains, has traditionally relied on religious themes, the supernatural, and sexuality. The figure of the kyai -- an Islamic scholar and relgious leader --  featured prominently in narratives as a means of making their otherwise scandalous subject matter viable under strict censorship laws. Yet changing tastes and politics have altered the meaning of kyai and, in the case of reality TV, the kyai has been repurposed as proof of the "realness" of ghosts and other phenomena.

Title: Baby Boomers and Popular Culture: An Inquiry Into America's Most Powerful Generation
Author: Cogan, Brian and Thom Gencarelli (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Cogan, Brian, and Thom Gencarelli, editors. Baby Boomers and Popular Culture: An Inquiry Into America's Most Powerful Generation. ABC-CLIO, 2015.
Horror Lex Summary: A survey of TV, film, music, and other popular culture that defined the post-war Baby Boom generation. In Chapter 10, author Todd K. Platts explores "The New Horror Movie" that emerged in the late 1960s. As he explains, relatively genteel gory comics and family-friendly TV horror hosts offered boomers "glimmers of hope and comfort in their childhood." Yet later films of the apocalyptic tradition, beginning with Night of the Living Dead in 1968, "effectively captured the nightmares of their young adulthood," including the Vietnam War, the breakdown of the nuclear family, and environmental catastrophe.

Title: Nightmare Japan: Contemporary Japanese Horror Cinema
Author: McRoy, Jay
Horror Lex Summary:
One of the only authors out there focusing on the horror film in Japan, McRoy offers this second work to delve deeper into the nation's special contributions to the genre. (His first was 2005's Japanese Horror Cinema, an anthology.) This is not an encyclopedia, but rather a thoughtful thesis on the intersection between film and culture. McRoy takes into account radical shifts in Japan's post-World War II economy, politics, and gender roles, as well as its "re-conceptualisations of the very notion of cultural and national boundaries."

Each chapter focuses on a particular corner of Japanese film -- and boy, does McRoy know how to pick the most gruesome corners. Chapters 1 and 2 address the extreme end of faux snuff and body horror/torture films, such as the Guinea Pig series, which McRoy traces back to several historical points in which the body of Japanese culture was at risk from Westernization and a threatened national identity. Genital censorship and Japanese ideals of bodily purity and sexuality, deeply skewered in the "pink" films (pinku eiga), are considered in Chapter 2, along with reactions to Japanese feminism and technology. Chapter 3 concerns the tentpole films that comprise the conventional definition of J-horror (Ringu, etc.) and the dual threat-promise of technology in postmodern Japan.

McRoy is at his most compelling when tackling themes that make little sense outside a Japanese cultural context, such as his discussion of ijime, or "dove-style violence," in films such as All About Lily Chou-Chou (2001) and Ichi the Killer (2001) (Chapter 4). These utterly disturbing flicks depict collective atrocities by an in-group against an outsider, which McRoy identifies as Darwinian in nature and "a component of a larger paradigmatic cycle of violence and suffering permeating contemporary Japanese culture." In Chapter 5, he delves into the peculiarly post-war Japanese version of apocalypse, marked by social alienation, self-sacrifice (Suicide Club (2002)) and cosmic patterns working through technology (Spiral/Uzumaki (2000) and Pulse/Kairo (2001)). 

If there is any flaw in McRoy's approach in Nightmare Japan, it is his tendency to throw too much at the audience. There are a lot of ideas mashed together here, and just when he's getting to a solid point, he often whips around to make a completely different one. But in terms of a true cultural analysis of Japan and horror, you cannot do better.

Title: Femicide: The Politics of Woman Killing
Author: Radford, Jill and Diana E.H. Russell (Eds.)
MLA 8 Citation: Radford, Jill, and Diana E.H. Russell, editors. Femicide: The Politics of Woman Killing. Tawyne, 1992.
Horror Lex Summary:
Radford and Russell's book, a collection of essays from guest authors, addresses the ever-controversial topic of violence toward women -- in real life, and in pop culture imagery. 

In her chapter, author Jane Caputi (a well-known historian of myth and the horror genre) tackles the grim end of the latter subject: pornography and gore films. Caputi is firmly on the side of anti-porn feminists, and draws a direct line between mistreatment of women in pornographic films and the rape and killing of women, which she calls "a fundamental need of the masculinist [patriarchal] state." For gore-horror, she is no more forgiving -- in fact, she notes the similarities between two particular films, one deemed softcore porn and the other a horror film, but both depicting sexual torture of women. Caputo sees the extreme end (snuff films, real or fake) as merely different in degree from the popular end (Psycho, slasher films, even fashion advertisements) and condemns them all.
Films Discussed:
Caputi, Jane - Advertising Femicide: Lethal Violence against Women in Pornography and Gorenorgraphy
・Friday the 13th (1980)
・Obsession: A Taste for Fear (a.k.a. Pathos - Segreta inquietudine) (1988)
・Pieces (1982)
・Psycho (1960)
・The Toolbox Murders (1978)

Title: Haunted: On Ghosts, Witches, Vampires, Zombies, and Other Monsters of the Natural and Supernatural Worlds
Author: Braudy, Leo
MLA 8 Citation: Braudy, Leo. Haunted: On Ghosts, Witches, Vampires, Zombies, and Other Monsters of the Natural and Supernatural Worlds. Yale UP, 2016.
Horror Lex Summary:
What makes us afraid? Author Braudy tackles several centuries of history and a wide array of monsters in art and myth to comment on how fear is shaped and, in turn, shapes our world. 

Braudy's consideration of horror in film (as opposed to literature) is spotty throughout most of the book, but he gives sustained attention to a few select works. This includes 1931's Dracula, which Braudy includes as part of his analysis of the Gothic pull of the monstrous past, as well as the preoccupation with the sexual power of women. He also devotes Chapter 8, Horror in the Age of Visual Reproduction, to film, discussing the unique abilities of the medium to deepen the horror response in viewers while modernizing ancient tropes.
